num construction when the plans require protect end bent piles from negative skin friction by using one of the following methods .
a .
method a after driving the end bent piles and before installing the earth reinforcing elements num .
place a cylindrical can over each pile to prevent the earth wall backfill material from contacting the pile .
section numpile protection in earth walls num use a can large enough in diameter to give a numin num mm minimum clearance from the pile to the inside of the can .
num .
place a spacer between the pile and the can to prevent the can from contacting the pile during wall backfilling .
extend the cans from the bottom of the earthstabilized backfill to the bottom of the bridge end bent cap .
num .
after positioning the cans seal them at the top while backfilling to keep rubbish or aggregate out of the can .
keep the cans sealed until fill settlement time has expired .
num .
when the wall backfill has reached the bottom of the cap and fill settlement time has expired fill the cans with aggregate .
b .
method b cover the piles with the following amounts of corrosioninhibiting grease as follows steel piling num in num mm minimum concrete piling num in num mm minimum num .
apply grease only after driving the piles .
treat only the pile portion that will be in contact with the wall backfill .
num .
in addition to the grease install a urethane or polypropylene sleeve to protect the grease coating from the backfill .
num .
use sprayon or preformed sleeves .
replace portions of the sleeve damaged or removed by construction activities during backfill .

num section numtunnel liner num general description this work includes driving a tunnel furnishing and installing steel plates for tunnel liner furnishing and erecting brick portals to close each end of the tunnel when required pressure grouting construct to plan line grade and dimensions according to the applicable specifications .

num materials ensure that materials meet the following requirements material specification section liner plates astm a numa numm galvanizing bituminous coating and bolts num brick for portal num num a. liner plates construct the completed liner with a series of steel liner plates assembled with staggered longitudinal joints and fabricated to fit the tunnel cross section .
num .
characteristics use hotdipped galvanized bituminouscoated steel of the size thickness and sectional modulus specified .
use plates made of hotrolled coldformed steel that conform to astm a numa num m. use plates with the following mechanical properties before cold forming tensile strength num psi num mpa yield strength num psi num mpa elongation num in num mm num percent num .
grout intrusion nipples provide grout intrusion nipples num in num mm or larger in diameter in the top plates at intervals num ft num m or less .
this will permit grouting while the tunnel liner is erected .
for larger tunnels or where conditions make more grout openings advisable install additional plates with nipples at the top quarter points andor on each side between the top openings .
stagger these additional openings but keep the distance between them num ft num m or less in any one line .
num .
flanged joints form plates to provide circumferential flanged joints .
use longitudinal joints that are flanged or offset lap seam type .
punch plates for bolting on both longitudinal and circumferential seams or joints .
space bolts in circumferential flanges according to the manufacturers standard spacing .
space bolts a multiple of the plate length so that plates with the same curvature are interchangeable and will permit staggering of longitudinal seams .
num .
longitudinal seams for lapped longitudinal seams ensure that bolt size and spacing is according to the manufacturers standard but meets the longitudinal seam strength requirements of section num of aashto standard specifications for highway bridges .
galvanizing bituminous coating and bolts shall be in compliance with applicable information in section num .
b. grout use grout that consists of one part portland cement two parts masonry lime four parts mortar sand section numtunnel liner num two percent of an approved admixture i.e .
bentonite septamine stearex or hydrocide liquid a retardant where required use enough mixing water to produce a workable mixture of grout capable of being pumped into the voids created by tunneling .
c. brick brick for portal shall conform to section num and subsection num .
num delivery storage and handling general provisions num through num .
num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment a. pumping equipment provide pumping equipment for grouting operations .
use equipment with enough pump horsepower and grouting line pressure to completely fill voids without buckling or shifting the liner plates or damaging the roadway .
b .
water control when water control is required operate well points or other drainage systems in the vicinity of the tunnel construction limits .
num preparation general provisions num through num .
num fabrication general provisions num through num .
num construction excavate the tunnel using any of the following procedures full face heading and bench multiple drift do not use a full or partial shield a tunneling machine or other equipment that exerts a force on the liner plates to propel steer or stabilize the equipment .
prevent the overpassing roadway or railway section from settling when constructing tunnels by using poling plates brest boards shields soil solidification a combination of these methods section numtunnel liner num a .
installation of liner plates use the same type of liner plates for the full length of the tunnel .
flanged and lapped seam methods of construction are acceptable .
num .
general install selfsupporting steel liner plates according to the manufacturers recommendations .
do not leave more than num ft num m of tunnel unlined while tunneling .
do not leave more than num ft num mm of tunnel unlined at the end of the days operation .
num .
sealing before grouting tunnel liner segments seal that segment sufficiently between the liner plates and the surrounding soil to retain the grouting pressure .
place the seals in these locations at the tunnel entrance between grout intrusion nipples within num ft num mm of the end of the tunnel num .
pressure grouting pressure grout voids in the area outside the plates every num ft num m at the end of the work shift .
grout more frequently if soil conditions dictate .
num .
repair repair damaged spelter coating according to section num .
replace plates with damaged spelter or bituminous coatings at no additional cost to the department if the engineer determines they can not be repaired .
b .
safety schedule the work to avoid interfering with or endangering traffic flow on the highway or railway .
follow required safety measures specified in the manual on uniform traffic control devices .
num .
begin tunneling at one end of a pit that has been sheeted and shored as necessary .
comply with section num .
perform work below the level of the roadbed .
num .
complete tunneling at one location before beginning work at another .
num .
if the engineer determines that tunneling is endangering overpassing roadway or the traveling public stop tunneling until making the necessary corrections .
num .
provide a wellbraced temporary bulkhead against the face of the excavation when work stops while the heading is within num ft num m of railroad tracks or highway pavement .
num .
if distress occurs to roadway due to tunneling the contractor shall submit for approval a plan to repair the roadway .
c. portals close tunnel portals at each end using a threecourse mortared brick wall according to plan details .
erect one of the three courses inside the liner .
num quality acceptance ensure that the tunnel has a diameter essentially the same as the outside diameter of the liner plates .

section numrenovating existing pipe num general description this work includes furnishing and inserting helically corrugated metal pipe smoothlined corrugated polyethylene pipe high density polyethylene profile wall pipe and high density polyethylene solid wall pipe or a polyvinyl chloride pipe inside an existing metal pipe and pressure grouting the space between the two pipes .
num definitions general provisions num through num .
num related references a .
standard specifications section numfine aggregate section numportland cement section numadmixtures section numsteel pipe section numsmooth lined corrugated polyethylene pe culvert pipe section numwater section numlime section nummineral filler b. referenced documents gdt num num submittals general provisions num through num .
num materials ensure that materials meet the requirements of the following specifications section numrenovating existing pipe num material section corrugated steel pipe helically corrugated num smoothlined corrugated polyethylene pe culvert pipe num portland cement types i or ii num mineral filler limestone dust num fly ash type a num water num fine aggregate size no .
num num agricultural lime num use georgia standard numd to determine the metal thickness of the insert pipe .
for this work use agricultural lime that has num percent minimum passing the no .
num num µm sieve and num percent minimum passing the no .
num num µm sieve .
a .
high density polyethylene hdpe profile wall pipe use pipe liner that consists of a hdpe profile wall pipe that conforms to the requirements of astm f num .
polyethylene material shall have polyethylene pipe liners material designation of pe num and shall have a material cell classification per astm d num of numc or higher .
join hdpe profile wall pipe liner by thermal fusion extrusion welding per manufacturer specifications or provide a positive mechanical joint that meets the requirements of astm d num .
the joint shall be able to be pulled or pushed into the host pipe without joint separation .
b .
high density polyethylene hdpe solid wall pipe pipe liner shall consist of a hdpe solid wall pipe that conforms to the requirements of astm f num with an sdr of num .
polyethylene material shall have polyethylene pipe liners material designation of pe num and shall have a material cell classification per astm d num of numc .
join hdpe solid wall pipe liner by butt fusion per astm f num and the manufacturer specifications or provide a positive mechanical joint that meets the requirements of astm d num .
the joint shall be able to be pulled or pushed into the host pipe without joint separation .
c. polyvinyl chloride pvc pipe pipe liner shall consist of pvc corrugated pipe with a smooth interior that conforms to the requirements of astm f num .
pvc pipe shall have a minimum pipe stiffness of num psi num kpa when tested according to astm d num .
use pipe made of pvc compound with a cell classification per astm d num of numb .
join the pvc pipe liner with a pvc coupling that uses elastomeric sealing gaskets .
the assembled joint shall meet the performance requirements of astm d num .
the joint shall be able to be pulled or pushed into the host pipe without joint separation .
ensure that elastomeric seals meet the requirements of astm f num .
d. grout mixtures mix water with the dry ingredients to produce a grout with an efflux time from the flow cone of at least num seconds and no more than num seconds when tested according togdt num .
add cement cement and limestone dust or cement and fine aggregate to the batch proportions to produce the required consistency .
section numrenovating existing pipe num table of grout mixtures mix proportions percent by weight of dry materials dry materials grout types num num num num num cement num num num num num limestone dust num num num fly ash num num fine aggregate num num num delivery storage and handling general provisions num through num .
num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment a. batching use weight hoppers and scales for each dry material or calibrated volumetric batch hopper .
calibrate volumetric batch hoppers in increments equivalent to one num lb num kg bag of cement .
b. mixing use a watertight batchtype mixer capable of blending the various materials into a homogenous mixture .
c. grout pumping use a positivedisplacement pistontype pump or a screwtype worm pump equipped with the following discharge line with a positive cutoff valve at the nozzle end and a bypass return line to recirculate the grout back into a holding tank or mixer a nozzle or device at the end of the discharge line that will remain secure in the num in num mm grout pipe and free of leaks d. pulling provide equipment capable of pulling the new helically corrugated metal pipe .

num fabrication general provisions num through num .
num construction a. grout mixtures use the table of grout mixtures in subsection num.d grout mixtures .
section numrenovating existing pipe num b .
installation install pipe liner according to the manufacturers guidelines and as specified in the plans with the following requirements num .
clean and inspect the existing pipe before pulling or pushing the new pipe through .
num .
use a nose cone on all on all pipe liners .
the nose cone shall have enough strength to withstand pulling or pushing of the new pipe liner .
weld or bolt the nose cone to the end of the liner .
use a nose cone that includes a ring for attaching the pulling cable .
num .
after pulling or pushing the new pipe through the old one plug the space between the pipes at both ends with concrete or mortar .
insert a num in num mm grout pipe with threaded ends on the outside into the tops of the plugs at both ends of the pipes and screw on a threaded cap .
num .
after the pipe plugs have been in place long enough to develop strength to withstand pressure grouting remove the grout pipe caps .
connect the grout pump to the downstream grout pipe and pump grout into the void until it flows freely from the upstream grout pipe .
num .
after pumping is complete replace the grout pipe caps .

num construction schedule the work so that underdrain installations coincide with other operations on the project to prevent conflict damage or infiltration of materials .
a. excavation to intercept waterbearing strata excavate according to the details and elevation shown on the plans or to an increased depth if the engineer directs .
when the material in the bottom of the trench is unstable remove unstable material add approved granular material and compact to provide a stable foundation for the pipe .
b .
laying pipe lay pipe according to plan details with the perforations on the underside of the pipe unless otherwise directed by the engineer .
num .
lay bell and spigot and tongue and groove pipe with the bell or grooved end upstream and the bells embedded in the foundation material .
num .
firmly connect the joints .
num .
connect pipe and butt joints securely using the appropriate size and type of band or coupling .
num .
install the following miscellaneous items as indicated on the plans or otherwise specified pipe screens caps section numunderdrains num plugs ells wyes tees markers c. backfilling after laying the pipe place drainage aggregate in num in num mm layers .
compact each layer thoroughly until reaching the total plan depth .
do not disturb pipe alignment .
d. marking mark each outlet end of the drainage system according to plan details .
e. protecting from contamination protect the filter material from contamination by foreign matter .
num .
particular attention must be given to the top surface of the filter blanket when it will be covered by an aggregate drainage course .
soil infiltration from placing soil courses over the filter material is incidental to the work and is not considered contamination .
num .
if aggregates become contaminated remove the contaminated portion and replace it with clean filter material before placing succeeding layers of filter blanket or placing aggregate drainage course .
num quality acceptance general provisions num through num .
num contractor warranty and maintenance general provisions num through num .

num payment each size of underdrain pipe will be paid for at the contract price per linear foot meter as follows a. underdrain pipe only payment for pipe under this item will include ground preparation excavation backfilling disposal of surplus material all appurtenances required to complete the item including screens tees wyes ells and markers section numunderdrains num b. underdrain pipe including drainage aggregate payment for pipe under this item will include specified drainage aggregate and all items listed under subsection num.a above .
underdrain pipe including drainage aggregate to depths greater than num ft num m below the final elevation established for the top of the trench will have an adjusted unit price .
this price will be computed by increasing the contract unit price by a percentage based on the extra depth as follows from over num ft num m to and including num ft num m at contract price plus num percent over num ft num m deep by supplemental agreement or force account c. contaminated aggregate removal and replacement of contaminated aggregate will not be paid for separately but will be included in the bid price for underdrain pipe .

before compacting establish the target density as num times the average of num drydensity determinations made on the material in the trench .
space the num determinations over at least num ft num m and determine them using the numin num mm direct transmission density mode according to gdt num .
num .

num .

to direct the water to the inlets crown the roadbed and construct a roll of embankment material at the shoulder line .

keep gutters pipes and inlets open .
num .
stage num construction complete this second stage operation immediately after paving shoulders to provide a complete drainage installation and prevent erosion of the embankment slopes .

b .

finish to a smooth firm surface .

thoroughly compact by rolling .

shape and complete the shoulders and slopes to conform to the required finished section .

ensure that the sealing rings for containing the elastomer in the pot bearings are as specified by the pot bearing manufacturer and meet the following requirements made of brass or stainless steel withstands and transmits all imposed loading allows free movement of the piston contains the elastomer within the pot under the maximum static and dynamic loading prevents contamination of the elastomer with foreign matter e. expanded mortar set anchor bolts in preformed or drilled holes using expanding mortar that meets the requirements of section num .

num stainless steel sliding surface to completely cover ptfe surface in all operating positions of the bearing .
num position the stainless steel sliding surface so that the sliding movement causes the dirt and dust accumulation to fall from the surface of the stainless steel .
b. ptfe sliding surface do not use holes of slots in the ptfe sliding surface .
c. static coefficient of friction under a load of num psi num mpa do not exceed num percent for unfilled ptfe nor num percent of filled ptfe surfaces .
d. rotation num radians .
section numpot bearings num e. pistoncylinder clearance limit clearance to num in num mm .
use a brass or stainless steel sealing ring to prevent extrusion of the elastomeric material .

num .
all control dimensions are maintained and bearings fit within the limits of detailed masonry plate .

num .

num .
protect the pot bearings from damage during construction and prevent contamination of the various components of the pot bearings .

during transportation and storage cover the bearings with moistureproof and dustproof covers .

num fabrication a. polytetrafluroethylene ptfe ensure that the ptfe including its connection to its backup material conforms with the requirements of section num except as modified in this specification .

num construction a. erection place bearings at their proper locations before erecting the superstructure supported by the bearings .
num .

num .
install the anchor bolts cast anchor bolts in the concrete or set them in preformed holes unless otherwise shown on the plans .
if setting them in preformed holes fill the preformed holes in the concrete substructure with epoxy grout .
a. insert the anchor bolts to the prescribed depth .
b .
place additional grout as required in the annular space around the anchor bolts until the grout is well packed and flush with the top surface of the concrete .
section numpot bearings num c. wipe clean the exposed surfaces of the anchor bolts and substructure .
do not allow a load on grout that has not been in place at least num days .
num .
install masonry plates set the masonry plates to the proper elevation on the previously finished concrete pads .
num .
install the bearings a .
place the bearing at the predetermined locations when erecting the superstructure .
b .
remove the temporary restraints as directed by the bearing manufacturer .
c. adjust the bearings as follows adjust the expansion bearings from the normal position at num f num c to allow for the ambient temperature during erection or casting .
adjust the pot bearings to allow them to move when dead loads are applied .
ensure that the bearing is properly positioned and parallel free from rotation after applying the dead load .
adjust the bearings horizontally on the masonry plate to properly fit the superstructure members being erected .
d. after adjustments and approval by the engineer weld the bearings to the masonry plate .

provide prototype pot bearings if used at no additional expense to the department .
specific items tested are as follows a. coefficient of friction perform tests to determine the static coefficient of friction of the first movement under a load of num psi num mpa on a piston area applied continuously for num hours before testing .
determine under a load of num psi num mpa on a piston area the following num .
the static coefficient of friction value shall not exceed num percent for filled ptfe surfaces and num percent for unfilled ptfe surfaces .
num .
the first movement static and dynamic coefficient of friction at a sliding speed of less than num in per min num mm per sec .
values shall not exceed num percent for filled ptfe surfaces and num percent for unfilled ptfe surfaces .
num .
the static and dynamic coefficient of friction is determined after the bearing is subjected to num design movements at a speed of less than num ft per min num mm per sec .
values shall not exceed those indicated in step num above .
signs of bond failure or other defects are cause for pot bearing rejection .
b .
proof loading perform under maximum design loads proof loading and compression deflection tests on a fullsize pot bearing .
section numpot bearings num c. cold flow subject an approved sample of filled ptfe or unfilled ptfe to a static pressure of num psi num mpa for at least num hours .
ensure that the ptfe material is bonded or mechanically connected to its backup material in the same way as the pot bearing .
apparent cold flow of the ptfe material is cause for pot bearing rejection .

num section numcontrolled low strength flowable fill num general description this work consists of furnishing and placing readymixed or volumetric mixed flowable fill as an alternate to compacted soil as approved by the engineer .
applications for this material include beddings encasements and closures for tanks and pipe and general backfill for trenches and abutments .

num related references standard specifications section numconcrete structures section numfine aggregate section numportland cement section numadmixtures section numwater referenced documents sopnum general provisions num through num .

num materials all materials shall meet the requirements of the following specifications material section fine aggregate subsection num portland cement subsection num fly ash subsection num airentraining admixtures subsection num water subsection num notes gradation requirement is waived .
the requirements of subsection num will be waived for fly ash .
high air generators or foaming agents may be used in lieu of conventional air entraining admixtures and may be added at the job site and mixed according to the manufacturers recommendation .
num delivery storage and handling general provisions num through num .
section numcontrolled low strength flowable fill num num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment general provisions num through num .
num preparation mix design flowable fill can be batched by readymix or volumetrically mixed on site .
readymixed flowable fill is a mixture of portland cement fly ash fine aggregate air entraining admixture and water .
ready mixed flowable fill contains a low cement content for reduced strength development .
volumetric mixed flowable fill is a mixture of class c fly ash or portland cement class f fly ash and water mixed on site .
num .
submit mix designs for flowable fill to the engineer for approval by the office of materials .
the following table lists mix design proportion ranges for excavatable and nonexcavatable flowable fill table nummix designs for flowable fill readymixed volumetric mixed excavatable nonexcavatable excavatable nonexcavatable cement type i num lbsydnum num kgmnum num lbsydnum num kgmnum num lbsydnum num kgmnum num lbsydnum num kgmnum class c fly ash num lbsydnum num kgmnum num lbsydnum num kgmnum class f fly ash num lbsydnum num kgmnum num lbsydnum num kgmnum num lbsydnum num kgmnum water air num to num num na na numday compressive strength maximum num psi num kpa minimum num psi num kpa maximum num psi num kpa minimum num psi num kpa unit weight wet num lbsftnum num kgmnum num lbsftnum num kgmnum num lbsftnum num kgmnum num lbsftnum num kgmnum amounts singly or in combination to make the mix yield one cubic yard meter .
mix designs shall produce a consistency that will result in a flowable selfleveling product at time of placement .
the requirements for percent air compressive strength and unit weight are for laboratory designs only and are not intended for jobsite acceptance requirements .
section numcontrolled low strength flowable fill num num fabrication readymixed ensure readymixed flowable fill is manufactured at plants that qualify as approved sources according to the standard operating procedure for quality assurance for readymix concrete plants in georgia sopnum .
mix and deliver according to subsection num of the specifications or other methods approved by the engineer .
revolution counter requirements are waived .
volumetric mixed ensure volumetric mixed flowable fill is manufactured through the use of volumetric mixers according to subsection num of the specifications or other methods approved by the engineer .
num construction when using as backfill for pipe where flotation or misalignment may occur assure correct alignment of the pipe by using straps soil anchors or other approved means of restraint .
protect flowable fill from freezing for num hours after placement .

num construction construct this work according to the following requirements a .
preparing the foundations prepare the ground surface where the rip rap will be placed to conform with the correct lines and grades before beginning the placement .
num .
when filling depressions compact the new material with hand or mechanical tampers .
dispose of excess material by spreading it neatly within the rightofway as an incidental part of the work .
num .
unless otherwise shown or provided below begin placing the rip rap in a toe ditch constructed in original ground around the toe of the fill or the cut slope .
ensure that the toe ditch is num ft num mm deep in original ground and the side next to the fill or cut has the same slope .
section numrip rap num num .
after placing the rip rap backfill the toe ditch and spread the excess dirt neatly within the rightofway as an incidental part of the work .
num .

ensure that the width and thickness of this apron is as shown on the plans or determined by the engineer .
b .
placing stone rip rap place rip rap to the limits shown on the plans or as directed by the engineer .
place and classify rip rap as follows num .
stone plain rip rap dump and handle stone plain rip rap into place to form a compact layer to the design thickness .
ensure that the thickness tolerance for the course is plus num in num mm with no undertolerance .
if the plans do not show a thickness place stone rip rap to at least num in num mm thick but no greater than num ft num mm thick .
num .
stone dumped rip rap dump stone dumped rip rap into place to form a uniform surface as thick as specified in the plans .
a .
ensure that the thickness tolerance for the course is minus num in num mm and plus num in num mm .
if the plans or proposal do not specify a thickness place the course to at least num ft num mm thick .
b .
recycled concrete that meets the requirements of subsection num may be used instead of stone when shown on the plans or approved by the engineer .
use recycled concrete only when materials do not contain steel after processing .
note do not use recycled concrete in aesthetically sensitive areas .
num .
stone grouted rip rap place stone grouted rip rap according to specifications for stone plain rip rap and these guidelines a .
prevent earth from filling the spaces between the stones .
b .
after placing the stone fill the spaces between them with num grout composed of portland cement and sand mixed thoroughly with enough water to make a thick creamy consistency .
c. place the grout beginning at the toe .
finish it by sweeping with a stiff bristle broom .
d. after grouting cover the rip rap and keep it wet for num days or cover and keep wet for num hours and then coat with white pigmented membrane curing compound .
c. placing filter place woven plastic filter fabric under all rip rap .
follow these requirements for placing the filter fabric num .
prepare the surface to receive the fabric until it is smooth and free from obstructions depressions and debris .
num .
place the fabric with the long dimension running up the slope .
minimize the number of overlaps .
num .
place the strips to provide a width of at least num ft num mm of overlap for each joint .
num .
anchor the filter fabric in place with securing pins of the type recommended by the fabric manufacturer .
place the pins on or within num in num mm of the centerline of the overlap .
num .
place the fabric so that the upstream strip will overlap the downstream strip .
num .
loosely place the fabric to prevent stretching and tearing during stone placement .
do not drop the stones more than num ft num m during construction .
num .
always protect the fabric during construction from clogging due to clay silts chemicals or other contaminants .
num .
remove contaminated fabric or fabric damaged during installation or rip rap placement .
replace with uncontaminated or undamaged fabric at no expense to the department .
d. placing sandcement bag rip rap place rip rap to the limits shown on the plans or as directed by the engineer .
section numrip rap num num .
proportioning materials mix sand and portland cement at the maximum ratio of num by weight .
a .
obtain a minimum compressive strength of num psi num mpa in num days .
b .
for sandcement bag rip rap use enough water to make up the optimum moisture content of the aggregate and cement as determined by aashto t num. c. when sandcement rip rap is to be prebagged mix the sand cement dry .
after placing each course wet the bags until the bags are wet enough for proper cement hydration .
num .
placement before placing sandcement bag rip rap fill the bags full but allow room to tie the bags .
a .
place the bagged rip rap by hand with the tied ends facing the same direction .
produce close broken joints .
b .
place header courses when directed by the engineer or required by the plans .
c. after placing the bags ram or pack them against one another to produce the required thickness and form a consolidated mass .
d. do not allow the top of each bag to vary more than num in num mm above or below the required plane .
e. placing stone blanket protection ensure that the stone blanket protection meets the materials specifications for stone filter blanket as specified in subsection num materials except stone size no .
num will be allowed instead of size no .
num .
place stone blanket protection to the limits shown on the plans or as directed by the engineer .
uniformly place this material to the thickness shown on the plans and to a thickness tolerance of num in num mm .
do not use stone blanket protection on slopes steeper than two horizontal to one vertical or in areas highly susceptible to erosion .
do not use plastic filter fabrics with stone blanket protection .
num quality acceptance general provisions num through num .
num contractor warranty and maintenance general provisions num through num .
num measurement this work is measured for payment in square yards meters of accepted material of the specified thickness .
area measurements are made parallel to the surface on which the material is placed .
plastic filter fabric will be measured as the area of rip rap placed and accepted .
no separate measurement will be made for fabric overlap joints seams or vertical sections at toe of slopes .
no separate measurement is made for grout or cushioning sand .
plan dimensions are figured by the use of filled bags num by num by num in .
num by num by num mm thick .
when filled bags are less than plan dimensions or are of varying lengths or width plan square yards meters will be used to determine pay quantities if overall dimensions are equal to or greater than those shown on the plans .

section numrubble masonry num general description this work includes constructing rubble masonry from classes such as coursed random and random range work from roughly squared and dressed stone laid with or without mortar as specified on the plans .
num definitions general provisions num through num .
num related references a .
standard specifications section nummasonry materials b. referenced documents general provisions num through num .
num submittals general provisions num through num .
num materials ensure that materials meet the requirements of the following specifications material section stone for masonry num mortar and grout num num delivery storage and handling general provisions num through num .
num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment general provisions num through num .
section numrubble masonry num num preparation general provisions num through num .
num fabrication general provisions num through num .
num construction construct rubble masonry as follows a .
shaping the stone roughly square the stones on joints beds and faces .
at angles and ends of walls use selected stone roughly squared and pitched to line .
if specified finish the corners or angles in exterior surfaces with a chisel draft .
before laying the stone in the wall shape and dress it so that it will not loosen after it is placed .
no dressing or hammering which will loosen the stone will be permitted after it is placed .
b .
laying the stone num .
decrease the stone thickness from the bottom to the top of wall .
num .
ensure that the headers in the heart of the wall are the same size as shown in the face and extend at least num in num mm into the core or backing .
num .
ensure that headers in walls num ft num mm or less in thickness extend entirely through the wall .
the headers shall occupy at least num percent of the face of the wall .
num .
lay the masonry to line and in roughly leveled courses .
ensure that the bottom of the foundation is large selected stones .
num .
lay the courses with leaning beds parallel to the natural bed of the material .
num .
regularly diminish the thicknesses of the courses if varied from the bottom to the top of the wall .
keep a surplus supply of stones at the site to select from .
num .
when mortar masonry is specified a .
clean each stone and saturate it with water before setting it .
clean and moisten the bed that will receive it .
b .
bed the stones in freshly made mortar with full joints .
carefully settle the stones in place before the mortar sets .
c. do not permit spalls in the beds .
ensure that the joints and beds have an average thickness of not more than num in .
num mm .
d. ensure that the vertical joints in each course break with the adjoining courses at least num in .
num mm .
e. do not place vertical joints directly above or below a header joint .
if a stone is moved or if the joint is broken after the mortar has set take the stone up and thoroughly clean the mortar from the bed and joints .
reset the stone in fresh mortar .
do not lay the masonry in freezing weather or when the stone contains frost except by permission and subject to required conditions .
note do not lay the masonry in freezing weather or when the stone contains frost except with permission .
f. whenever possible properly point the face joints before the mortar sets .
if joints can not be pointed rake them out to a depth of num in num mm before the mortar sets .
do not smear the stone face surfaces with the mortar forced out of the joints or the mortar used in pointing .
g. thoroughly wet the joints pointed after the stone is laid with clean water and fill with mortar .
h. drive the mortar into the joints and finish with an approved pointing tool .
i .
keep the wall wet while pointing .
in hot or dry weather protect the pointed masonry from the sun and keep it wet for at least three days after the pointing is finished .
section numrubble masonry num note do not perform pointing in freezing weather or when the stone contains frost .
j .
after the pointing is completed and the mortar is set thoroughly clean the walls and leave them in a neat condition .
num .
dry rubble masonry when laying dry rubble a .
take care that each stone takes a firm bearing no less than in three separate points upon the underlying course .
b .
ensure that face joints are no greater than num in num mm wide .
c. chink the open front and rear joints with spalls fitted to take firm bearing upon the top and bottom surfaces throughout the length of the stone .
d. fill the interstices in the heart of the wall with spalls .
when specified thoroughly slush the open joint on the rear surfaces with mortar to prevent water from seeping through the joints .
c. weep holes provide adequate drainage for retaining walls with weep holes as shown on the plans or required by the engineer .
when backfilling at weep holes build chimneys and french drains extending through the parts of the fill to be drained .
the cost of chimneys weep holes and french drains is included in the contract price for rubble masonry .
d. copings use copings bridge seats and back walls made from the materials shown on the plans .
if not otherwise specified they shall be class a concrete .
make concrete copings in sections at least num in num mm thick and from num to num ft num to num m long extending the full width of the wall .
cast the sections in place or precast and set them in place in free mortar beds .
num quality acceptance general provisions num through num .
num contractor warranty and maintenance general provisions num through num .
num measurement this work is measured in cubic yards meters of accepted masonry .
the dimensions shown on the plans shall be used except for changes made by the engineer .
excavation for rubble masonry is not measured for separate payment .
num limits general provisions num through num .
num payment this work will be paid for at the contract price per cubic yard meter for mortar rubble masonry or dry rubble masonry complete in place .
payment will be made under item no .
num mortar rubble masonry per cubic yard meter item no .
num dry rubble masonry per cubic yard meter num adjustments general provisions num through num .
num section numbrick masonry num general description this work includes laying brick in mortar .
num definitions general provisions num through num .
num related references a .
standard specifications section numexcavation and backfill for minor structures section nummasonry materials b. referenced documents general provisions num through num .
num submittals general provisions num through num .
num materials ensure that the materials meet the requirements of the following specifications brick for masonry num mortar and grout num num delivery storage and handling general provisions num through num .
num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment general provisions num through num .
num preparation general provisions num through num .
num fabrication general provisions num through num .
num construction a .
brick selection select brick for exposed surfaces corners etc .
from brick approved as to color and uniformity .
b .
laying brick follow these guidelines when laying brick section numbrick masonry num num .
saturate the brick with water before laying it .
num .
lay the brick using the shovejoint method to bond it thoroughly into the mortar .
num .
arrange headers and stretchers to bond the mass thoroughly .
num .
for straight masonry walls using stretcher courses ensure that at least num course in num is a header course .
num .
finish joints properly as the work progresses .
create joints at least num in num mm but no more than num in num mm thick .
note do not use spalls or bats except to shape around irregular openings or to use at corners .
num .
lay brick evenly and neatly .
c. observing weather limitations do not lay brick in freezing weather or when the bricks contain frost except with permission from the engineer and when required .
in hot and dry weather protect the masonry and keep it wet for at least num hours after laying the brick .
d. backfilling do not place backfill against the masonry until it is at least num days old .
during cold weather the restricted period may be longer as directed .
num quality acceptance all brick masonry shall present an even uniform neat and workmanlike appearance .
num contractor warranty and maintenance general provisions num through num .
num measurement this work is measured for payment by one of the two methods specified below .
the unit of measurement is stated in the contract .
separate payment is not made for brick masonry used in catch basins inlets manholes and similar items which are measured and paid for per each .
excavation and backfill for this work is not measured for payment except as specified in section num .
mortar is not paid for separately and the cost is included in the contract price for brick masonry .
a .
measurement by cubic meter when brick masonry is measured by the cubic yard meter the volume measured is the brick and mortar placed within the lines indicated on the plans and typical cross sections or as directed by the engineer .
b .
measurement by number of bricks when brick masonry is measured by the brick the unit of measurement is each thousand m bricks and fraction placed within the lines indicated on the plans and typical cross sections or as directed by the engineer .

section numremoval of portland cement concrete roadway slabs num general description this work includes removing the full depth of existing jointed portland cement concrete pavement slabs of various lengths .
the slabs to be removed are shown on the plans or are designated by the engineer .
num definitions general provisions num through num .
num related references a .
standard specifications section numepoxy resin adhesives b. referenced documents general provisions num through num .
num submittals general provisions num through num .
num materials general provisions num through num .
num delivery storage and handling general provisions num through num .
num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment general provisions num through num .
num preparation general provisions num through num .
num fabrication general provisions num through num .
num construction the engineer will determine which slabs to remove and replace and whether to use full or partial slab replacement .
section numremoval of portland cement concrete roadway slabs num a .
partial slab replacements the engineer will determine the limits of removal .
remove and replace at least num ft num m of slab measured longitudinally and num ft num m measured transversely .
any slab removal beyond the limits determined by the engineer will be at no additional cost to the department for removal and replacement .
num .
saw the slab full depth longitudinally along the centerline joint and shoulder joint and transversely along the area marked for removal including transverse joints where applicable .
a .
if approved by the engineer omit the shoulder joint cut if doing so does not damage the shoulder .
b .
if necessary and if approved by the engineer make additional cuts within the removal area to remove the damaged slab more easily .
num .
thoroughly remove saw slurry and other contaminants from the overcutting beyond limits of the removal area .
repair by filling the overcuts with type ii epoxy adhesive that meets the requirements of section num .
clean and fill the overcuts as soon as possible but no later than when the joints are sealed .
num .
remove the damaged slabs by lifting .
do not fragment the slabs for removal unless approved by the engineer .
num .
drill holes in each slab section to accommodate the expanding type lift anchors .
remove sections nearest the centerline joint first to minimize damage to the shoulder .
note during removal avoid damaging the pavement base shoulder or sides that will not be removed .
num .
repair the damaged shoulder area to the engineers satisfaction at the contractors expense .
num .
if the adjacent concrete pavement is damaged during removal enlarge the removal area to include the damaged sections of adjacent concrete .
all applicable rules regarding the minimum size of remaining slab will apply as shown on the plans .
remove and replace additional slab lengths damaged from removing the initial slab at the contractors expense .
num .
remove loose underlying base material to produce a sound wellcompacted base .
num .
thoroughly tamp the material loosened in the removal process to the engineers satisfaction before replacing the slab .
num .
dispose of the slabs and underlying base material removed during this work .
num .
obtain the disposal site and necessary permits and agreements .
num quality acceptance general provisions num through num .
num contractor warranty and maintenance general provisions num through num .
num measurement slabs and portions of slabs removed are measured by the square yard meter using the average squared dimensions .
removing underlying base material and cleaning and repairing overcuts is not measured for payment .
num limits general provisions num through num .
num payment slabs and portions of slabs measured as specified in subsection num measurement above will be paid for at the contract unit price bid .
payment is full compensation for sawing cleaning repairing overcutting and removing and disposing of the concrete and any underlying base material .
payment will be made under section numremoval of portland cement concrete roadway slabs num item no .
num remove roadway slab per square yard meter num adjustments general provisions num through num .
section numremoval of miscellaneous roadway items num general description this work includes removing salvaging or disposing of items listed in the proposal as pay items to be removed and backfilling the excavations made during removal .

num definitions general provisions num through num .
num related references a .

num materials num delivery storage and handling a .
materials retained by the department unless removed under sections num num or num or unless otherwise provided for in the plans or proposal carefully remove materials with a salvage value .
num .
neatly stack or stockpile the materials along the rightofway near the removal point and above high water .
num .
store highway signs standing on edge and protected from the elements .
num .
replace materials damaged defaced or destroyed by removing them carelessly at no cost to the department .
num .
notify the engineer when the materials have been stockpiled and are ready to be transported .
num .
keep materials secure and replace at the contractors expense materials lost stolen or missing within a maximum of num days after the engineer has been notified that the materials are ready to be transported .
section numremoval of miscellaneous roadway items num b .
materials reused in the work maintain structures portions of structures and other materials to be salvaged and reused in reconstruction work .
assume responsibility for the material until project final acceptance .
repair or replace materials lost or stolen before reuse at the contractors expense .
spread suitable surplus excavation material on the slopes of the roadway embankments .
otherwise dispose of the waste materials off the rightofway at the contractors expense .
c. bridge components dispose of bridge components according to section num .
replace or repair at the contractors expense structures portions of structures or materials to be salvaged retained or used in the reconstructed work but that were carelessly damaged or destroyed by the contractor .
num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment general provisions num through num .
num preparation if removing a structure may endanger a new construction finish that part of the work before beginning the new construction .
num fabrication general provisions num through num .
num construction a .
protection of remaining structures do not use explosives equipment or devices that may endanger structures facilities or other property to remain in place .
if parts of structures are to remain in place protect them from damage during construction .
protect and preserve the salvage value of materials to be salvaged .
b .
extent of removal separate and remove existing structures with their attached parts and connections as shown on the plans or designated to be removed .
num .
when a part of an existing structure is to remain in place ensure that the part to be removed extends to a construction joint or is cut off to the lines shown on the plans leaving reasonably smooth faces .
remove walls and other masonry construction to the bottoms of the foundations unless otherwise specified .
num .
remove walls and their foundations within the roadbed area to an elevation at least num ft num mm below the top of the finished subgrade unless otherwise specified .
num .
see subsection num.c.num.c abandoned obstructions for guidelines for rigid surfaces .
c. railway tracks removing railway tracks includes removing rails ties switches towers concrete structures sign posts and other related railway structures .
leave ballast in place unless otherwise specified .
section numremoval of miscellaneous roadway items num d. inlets catch basins manholes and culverts num .
remove gratings traps and other metal castings of inlets catch basins and manholes without damaging them .
reuse them on new structures or salvage them whichever the engineer directs .
num .
remove old culverts down to the ground level or to the adjacent water level unless otherwise shown on plans .
num .
remove the bottom slabs of inlets catch basins manholes and culverts .
if the engineer permits them to remain in place break them up so that water will readily pass through them .
e. removing pipe uncover the pipe to remove it without damage .
exercise care in removing the pipe .
replace pipe sections damaged by negligence at the contractors expense .
after removing the pipe clean it and neatly stack it at points directed by the engineer along the line of the work .
unless otherwise specified the pipe is the property of the department .
f. septic tanks when encountering septic tanks completely remove the contents of each tank .
num .
remove and dispose of the tanks contents as required by the state department of health and local health authorities .
num .
before backfilling the remaining portion of the septic tank drill holes in the bottom of the tank or break it up as the engineer directs to permit drainage .
g. backfilling backfill trenches and other excavations dug for removing miscellaneous structures .
num .
use approved materials in the backfill .
num .
compact the backfill in layers no more than num in num mm thick and with the proper moisture content .
use pneumatic tampers or other approved equipment .
num .
under the roadway ensure that the degree of compaction conforms to section num .
elsewhere compact the backfill equal to the soil surrounding it .
h. structures to remain preserve unharmed the miscellaneous structures including fences buildings pipe lines pole lines water and sewer lines and other improvements that owners or the department will retain or that others will remove .
i. culverts to be extended where concrete culverts are to be extended remove a minimum amount of concrete in parapets wing walls and wing wall footings to clear the new construction .
make the joint or connection as shown on the plans or as directed by the engineer .
j .
fences when removing fences do not allow livestock to escape .
if fences are to be reset according to section num protect the spelter coating of fence fabric steel fence posts and braces .
the engineer will require that reusable posts removed be clean and free of concrete .
if desired furnish new posts instead of cleaning the old ones at no additional cost to the department .
k. raised edge curb remove raised edge curb to a reasonably true line at the elevation of normal finished pavement .
if the average of the plus and minus deviations approximate the original normal edge of pavement a tolerance of approximately num in num mm above or below this elevation will be accepted .
section numremoval of miscellaneous roadway items num do not shatter pavement that will be retained .
l. highway signs remove the entire sign from the supports and remove the supports from the concrete foundation .
m. lighting standards and appurtenances disassemble the lighting standard and separate each component part including the transformer base .
cut the underground duct before removing these items .
n. removal of existing building structures demolish remove and dispose of all building structures within the right of way and easement areas including concrete slabs footings foundations etc .
as shown on the plans .
grade all disturbed ground to a reasonably smooth and pleasing appearance free from loose boulders and other debris that would interfere with the use of power mowers .
grass all disturbed areas .
prior to demolition or removal num .
inspect all building structures for the presence of asbestos .
the inspection shall be done by an epa asbestos hazard emergency response act ahera accredited inspector whose certification is current .
num .
provide a copy of all inspection reports including the inspectors credentials to the engineer .
num .
provide written notice of intent to demolish to the georgia environmental protection division epd of the georgia department of natural resources in accordance with epd regulations with a copy to the engineer .
this notice is required even if there is no asbestos present .
if there is asbestos present its removal shall be done by a contractor licensed with the epd in accordance with the rules of georgia department of natural resource environmental protection division chapter num .
all asbestos removal and disposal shall be done in accordance with epd regulations .
all asbestos removal shall be considered as extra work and payment will be made in accordance with subsection num .

the engineer will check the design and request changes to ensure the design conforms with the specifications and the intended purpose .
after making the required changes resubmit the drawings to the engineer for final approval .
do not begin work on the dock until the drawings receive the engineers final approval .
num materials ensure that dock timber except timber used for handrails is creosotetreated according to section num .
piles for docks may be untreated but they must be peeled and have a minimum num in num mm butt diameter .

nails and hardware do not need to be galvanized .

note if repairs are not made promptly the engineer may make the repairs and have the costs deducted from the monies due the contractor .
num .

num .
when the dock was constructed for use on a previous project or contract assume responsibility for the dock and promptly restore and maintain it in a safe and satisfactory condition as directed by the engineer .
maintain the dock for the duration of the contract as directed by the engineer .
b. dock removal when the dock is no longer needed the engineer will direct in writing to remove it .
the salvaged material becomes the contractors property .

num definitions general provisions num through num .
num related references a .

section numjack or boring pipe num num submittals a .
handling method furnish for the engineers approval a plan showing the proposed method of handling including design for the jacking head jacking support or back stop arrangement and position of jacks pipe guides etc .
complete as assembled b. welding procedure before welding steel pipe or ductile iron pipe as casing and carrier submit to the state materials engineer a written welding procedure .
include joint details preheat temperature and electrodes to be used .
do not use welded steel pipe as a sanitary sewer carrier .
num materials use pipe types and sizes that conform to the plans and the following material section corrugated metal pipe num concrete pipe num steel pipe num ductile iron pipe plain ends num num delivery storage and handling general provisions num through num .
num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment general provisions num through num .
num preparation general provisions num through num .
num fabrication general provisions num through num .
num construction dispose of the excavated material from the following jacking or boring operations or use it as directed by the engineer at no additional cost to the department .
a. jacking follow these requirements when jacking num .
excavate suitable pits or trenches for the jacking operation and for placing the end joints of pipe when required .
securely sheet and brace the pits or trenches to prevent caving where necessary .
num .
when installing pipe under railroads highways streets or other facilities by jacking or boring perform construction and prevent section numjack or boring pipe num interfering with the facility operation weakening the roadbed or structure num .
to force the pipe through the roadbed use a jack with a head constructed to apply uniform pressure around the ring of the pipe .
num .
set the pipe to be jacked on guides braced together to properly support the pipe section and to direct it to the proper line and grade .
num .
excavate the roadbed as follows a. excavate roadbed material just ahead of the pipe .
b .
remove the excavated material through the pipe .
c. ensure that the excavation diameter conforms to the outside diameter and circumference of the pipe as closely as possible .
num .
force the pipe through the roadbed into the excavated space .
num .
use an approved mix to pressure grout voids that develop during installation and that the engineer determines are detrimental to the work .
num .
ensure that the excavation does not extend beyond the pipe more than num ft. num mm .
decrease the distance at the engineers direction or if the character of the excavated material allows .
num .
jack the pipe from the low or downstream end .
the line and grade from the pipes final position established by the engineer may vary no more than two percent in lateral alignment and one percent in vertical grade .
ensure that the final grade of the flow line is in the direction indicated on the plans .
num .
use a cutting edge around the head end .
extend it a short distance beyond the pipe end with inside angles or lugs to keep the cutting edge from slipping back into the pipe .
num .
once the pipe jacking has begun proceed with the operation without interruption to prevent the pipe from becoming firmly set in the embankment .
num .
remove and replace pipe damaged in jacking operations at no additional expense to the department .
num .
after completing the jacking immediately backfill the excavated pits or trenches .
b. boring proceed with the boring from a pit provided for boring equipment and workmen .
complete these steps num .
excavate for pits and shoring installation as outlined above .
num .
locate the pit at the engineers approval .
num .
bore the holes mechanically using a pilot hole approximately num in .
num mm in diameter that is bored the entire length of the installation .
a .
check the pilot hole for line and grade on the opposite end of the bore from the work pit .
b .
use the pilot hole to serve as the center line of the larger diameter hole to be bored .
num .
place excavated material near the top of the working pit and dispose of it as required .
use water or other fluids with the boring operation to lubricate the cuttings .
do not perform jetting .
num .
in unconsolidated soil formations use a gelforming collodial drilling fluid with at least num percent of high grade carefully processed bentonite to consolidate excavated material seal the walls of the hole and lubricate subsequent removal of material and immediate pipe installation .
num .
ensure that the diameter of the excavation conforms to the outside diameter of the pipe as closely as possible .
num .
see subsection num.a jacking for the allowable variation from line and grade .
num .
use an approved mix to pressure grout voids that develop during the installation operation and that the engineer determines are detrimental to the work .
num quality acceptance general provisions num through num .

num limits general provisions num through num .

payment is full compensation for furnishing the pipe and the incidentals to complete the item .
excavation will not be paid for separately but will conform to section num and section num .
payment will be made under item no .

section numpermanent anchored walls num general description this work includes furnishing materials labor tools equipment and other incidental items to design detail and construct an anchored wall .
this specification applies to any contractorproposed alternate design of departmentfurnished plans .
num definitions anchorsynonymous with the terms tieback or tiedown .
the term anchored wall includes the following items anchors soldier piles lagging facing drainage num related references a .
standard specifications section numconcrete structures section numreinforcement steel section numreinforcement and tensioning steel section numpermanent anchored walls num b. referenced documents general provisions num through num .
num submittals a .
proof of ability submit the following proof of ability or ability of the subcontractor when requested by the department to design or construct anchored walls evidence of successfully completing at least num projects similar in concept and scope to the proposed wall .
resumes of foremen anchor testing personnel and drilling operators to be employed on this project .
show the type length and number of ground anchors each has installed or tested within the past num years .
evidence of experience in anchor testing .
persons performing anchor testing must prove experience by performing sample tests supervised by the engineer .
the department is the sole judge of the qualifications of the foreman drilling operator and testing personnel .
do not begin wall construction until the engineer has approved proof of ability .
b .
design criteria for alternate design if the department receives more than num submittals of the plans and calculations for review the contractor will be assessed num per hour of engineering time for reviews in excess of the num submittals .
c. construction drawings and design notes if a contractorproposed alternate anchored wall is a part of the low bid submit construction drawings and design notes within num days of the date of award of the contract .
the design engineer shall prepare and stamp the submission .
include design notes and reproducible drawings in the submission concerning the following details dimensions and schedules of reinforcing steel including dowels or studs for attaching the facing to the tied back wall details of the anchors and soldier piling including spacing and size of piles and spacing and angle of anchor installation detailed plans for anchor proof and performance testing that show loading and measuring devices used and procedures followed d. wall final plans and calculations submit final wall plans and calculations to the department for review and approval before beginning construction on the wall the time required for plan and calculation preparation and review will be charged to the allowable contract time .
the department has num days for plan and calculation review per item after receiving the structure calculations and drawings .
new submittals from the contractor showing corrections from the departments review or changes to ease construction or to correct field errors have a numday review .
the department is the sole judge of information adequacy .
the departments review and acceptance of the final plans and construction methods does not relieve the contractor from successfully completing the work .
time extensions are not granted for contractor delays from untimely submissions and insufficient information .
e. admixture literature before using an admixture submit to the engineer the manufacturers literature .
indicate the admixture type and the manufacturers recommendations for mixing the admixtures with grout .
section numpermanent anchored walls num f. structural steel submit to the engineer the mill test reports for each heat or lot of prestressing material used to fabricate tendons .
num materials a .
concrete use concrete that conforms to section num .
b .
reinforcing steel use reinforcing steel that conforms to section num .
c. structural steel use structural steel as follows num .
use prestressing bars made of continuously threaded fulllength steel that conforms to astm designation a num type ii .
do not use couplers .
ensure material requirements coating application and epoxy coating sampling and testing conform to section num .
num .
use fulllength prestressing strands and wires according to section num .
d. cement grout produce cement grout using portland cement that conforms to aashto m num type i ii or iii and potable water .
use cement that is fresh and free of lumps and hydration .
follow these restrictions if using admixtures num .
do not use admixtures with chemicals that may harm the prestressing steel or cement .
num .
do not use expansive additives that cause air bubbles in the grout .
num .
if approved by the engineer use admixtures that will impart low water content flowability and minimum bleeding in the cement grout .
e. plastic for corrosion protection use polypropylene plastic that conforms to designation grade ii numd as per astm dnum .
ensure that the environmental stress crack resistance of the material prevents failures at num hours when tested by astm dnum .
f. corrosion inhibitor use corrosion inhibitor grease that conforms to the following test requirements drop point num f num c minimum by astm dnum flash point num f num c minimum by astm dnum water content num percent maximum by astm dnum rust grade num or better after num hours aggressive conditions rust grade num or better after num hours by astm bnum and astm dnum watersoluble ions must follow these requirements num .
oil separationnum percent by weight maximum at num f num c by fimsnumb method num num .
soak testnum percent salt fog at num f num c num mils num mm q panel type s. immerse panels in num percent salt solution and expose to num percent salt fogno emulsification after num hoursby astm bnum modified .
chlorides num ppm max by astm bnum nitrates num ppm max by astm dnum section numpermanent anchored walls num sulfates num ppm max by aphanumd num delivery storage and handling a .
protection systems protect prestressed rock and soil anchors against corrosion by properly storing fabricating and handling the tendon components before inserting them into the borehole .
avoid prolonged exposure of the tendon components to the elements and avoid mechanical or physical damage that reduces or impairs the components ability to resist adverse conditions during service .
tendon components will be rejected for heavy corrosion or pitting but not for a light coating of rust .
use the protection systems as follows num .
prestressing steel protect the entire length of prestressing steel from the anchor plate to the end of the tendon from corrosion .
a. encase the prestressing steel in a corrugated plastic tube .
b .
use cement grout to fill the voids between the tube and the prestressing steel and the tube and the soil .
fill the cement grout between the soil and the tube to at least num in num mm thick and extend the entire length of the tendon .
c. provide centralizers spaced a maximum of num ft num m centertocenter throughout the bond length .
do not use wood or material harmful to the tendon steel or corrugated plastic tubing as centralizers .
d. provide a smooth piece of plastic sheath to encapsulate the entire free length .
do not splice the sheath .
ensure that the sheath is at least num in num mm thick .
e. place a grease film compounded to lubricate and inhibit corrosion between the sheath and the prestressing steel in the entire free length .
ensure that the plastic sheath is seamless hot melt extruded polypropylene shrunk tightly onto the grease .
ensure that the sheath has a coefficient of friction with the steel of less than num and a wall thickness of at least num in .
num mm .
f. ensure that the sheath exerts a positive pressure on the grease .
ensure that the grease film is at least num in num mm thick .
minimize the void space between the sheath and the steel by filling visible void spaces with grease and sealing the bottom to keep the grout out .
num .
area underneath anchorage protect the area immediately behind the stressing anchorage .
a. weld a pipe sleeve to the bearing plate and seal the pipe sleeve to the anchor sheath at the other end of the sleeve .
b .
clean the pipe sleeve to remove dirt rust or other harmful material before inserting the tendon into the pipe sleeve .
c. if a seal is not provided at the lower end of the pipe sleeve during installation and grouting fill the lower end of the pipe sleeve with grout .
keep the pipe sleeve free of harmful material until the upper portion of the pipe sleeve and anchor head is filled with grout .
d. after stressing the anchors fill the void inside the sleeve and anchor head with antibleed expansion grout .
num .
anchorage encase the anchorage system head at each lift into a corrosion protective system before proceeding to the next lift .
install the protective system for each lift within num days after installing the anchors for that lift .
ensure that the anchorage system has a cover of at least num in num mm once the wall face is placed .
section numpermanent anchored walls num num construction requirements num personnel a .
contractor qualifications the contractor and subcontractor shall be experienced in designing or constructing permanently anchored walls .
provide at least one registered professional engineer licensed to perform work in the state of georgia and a supervising engineer for the project with at least num years of experience in constructing permanently anchored walls .
furnish verification of these qualifications to the engineer before beginning operations .
b .
design engineer the design engineer shall be registered as a professional engineer in the state of georgia have considerable knowledge and experience designing and constructing anchored walls be available at any time during the contract to discuss the design of the walls with the department c. registered professional engineer retain the services of a second registered professional engineer licensed to perform work in the state of georgia and prequalified by the department .
the engineer shall operate independently from the professional engineer of subsection num.a contractor qualifications .
this engineer will independently check the design calculations and plan details for the permanent anchored walls before submitting them to the department for review .
num equipment a. anchorage and hardware use anchorage and hardware suitable for the type of anchor tendon used .
ensure that anchorage and hardware are capable of the following developing num percent of the guaranteed specified minimum ultimate tensile strength of the tendon when tested in the unbonded state and without failure of the tendon holding a load of prestressing steel that produces a stress of at least num percent of the guaranteed specified minimum ultimate tensile strength of the prestressing steel without exceeding the anticipated set and without causing anchorage or prestressing steel failure liftingoff detensioning or retensioning a tendon before secondary grouting to fill voids at the top of the pipe sleeve b. anchor nut and plate for bars use anchor nuts and plates for bars that have complementary spherical shapes at the contact areas .
num preparation before beginning the work survey the condition of the adjoining properties .
keep records and photograph settlement or cracking of adjacent structures that may become the subject of possible damage claims .
deliver the report to the department before beginning work at the site .
obtain a foundation investigation report from the geotechnical engineering bureau of the department to assist in evaluating existing conditions for design and construction .
section numpermanent anchored walls num num fabrication a. tendons fabricate the tendons according to the approved details .
num .
keep the tendons free of dirt rust or other harmful substances .
num .
use a plastic sheath that is a single piece without splices .
num .
install the sheath at the fabrication shop not in the field .
num .
before installation handle and store the tendons so as to avoid corrosion and physical damage .
tendons will be rejected for damage such as abrasions cuts nicks welds weld splatters or heavy corrosion and pitting .
replace the tendons at the contractors expense for material replacements or time delays .
num .
repair damaged coatings in the field at the engineers approval .
num construction a .
design criteria for alternate design the design criteria for a proposed alternate or design include num .
design rock anchors and soil anchors according to this specification .
num .
assume responsibility for lagging .
design the lagging with sound engineering principles .
num .
use reinforced concrete facing according to the latest aashto standard specifications for highway bridges including interims .
ensure that the facing structural thickness is at least num in num mm .
perform architectural facing treatment as shown on the department drawings .
num .
ensure that the concrete strength for a proposed alternate is at least num psi num mpa numday strength .
extend the facing num ft num mm below the gutterline or if applicable the ground line adjacent to the wall unless otherwise indicated on the plans .
num .
design soldier piles for shear bending and axial stresses according to the latest aashto design criteria .
use steel or concrete soldier piles with a steel yield strength at least num psi num mpa .
ensure that the concrete has a numday strength of at least num psi num mpa .
num .
design and install permanent drainage systems behind the wall .
connect drainage systems to the nearest drop inlet using pipe or free drainage through traffic barriers or other obstructions .
ensure that holes through traffic barriers or facing are no higher than num in num mm above the gutterline or ground line .
num .
have the wall design account for live load dead load and wind load from traffic barriers lights overhead signs or other appendage on top or adjacent to the wall .
figure num figure num and figure num indicate loading conditions for soldier piles lagging and anchors at critical stages of construction .
section numpermanent anchored walls num figure num load case num soldier piles and lagging cantilevered during excavation for top row of anchors surcharge h temporary bottom of excavation a kp a ka b ka h ka ha ka a b ha kp hb kp design pressure diagram shall include the effect of surcharge loading note the above diagrams apply for cohesionless soils .
for cohesive soils the effect of cohesion may be considered .
where lagging is in place active earth pressure acts over the entire wall surface .
below lagging active earth pressure acts on ly on the soldier pile width and passive earth pressure is generated as follows a in sands and saprolitic soils with blow counts of num or greater passive pressure is generated over num times the soldier pile width .
b in clays nonsaprolitic silts and saprolitic soils with blow counts of num or less passive pressure is generated over the wid th of the soldier pile .
vertical component of anchor force must be resisted by embedded length of soldier piles below assumed excavation .
is the soil unit weight in pounds per cubic foot .
