num section numtriangular silt barrier num general description the work covered by this section consists of furnishing installing and removing waterpermeable triangular silt barriers used to remove suspended particles from drainage water .
num definitions general provisions num through num .
num related references a .
standard specifications section num b. referenced documents general provisions num through num .
num submittals general provisions num through num .
num materials a .
general triangular silt barriers shall have a waterpermeable urethane foam core surrounded by a woven geotextile fabric .
the foam core shall have a triangular crosssection with a minimum height of num in num mm in the center and a minimum base length of num in num mm .
the other two crosssectional sides shall be of equal length .
the fabric shall be wrapped around the foam core and shall extend beyond both sides of the triangle at least num in num mm .
b. filter fabrics filter fabrics shall be composed of strong rotproof synthetic fibers formed into a woven fabric .
the fabric shall be free of treatment or coating that might significantly alter its physical properties after installation .
the fabric shall contain stabilizers or inhibitors to make the filaments resistant to deterioration from exposure to sunlight or heat .
the fabric shall be a pervious sheet of synthetic fibers oriented into a stable network so that the fibers retain their relative position to each other under normal handling installation and service conditions .
edges of the fabric shall be finished to prevent the outer yarn from pulling away from the fabric .
fabrics shall be free of defects or flaws that would significantly affect its physical or filtering properties .
the fabric shall not be exposed to temperatures greater than num f num ºc .
the fabric shall meet the following physical requirements tensile strength pounds newtons min .
astm d num num warp num num fill num num elongation max .
astm dnum num aos apparent opening size max .
sieve size astm dnum num num µm flow rate gal minftnum litersmin.mnum gdt num num num section numtriangular silt barrier num ultraviolet stability num astm dnum after num hours weathering in accordance with astm dnum num bursting strength psi kpa astm dnum diaphragm bursting strength tester num num num minimum roll average of five specimens .
num percent of required initial minimum tensile strength .
c. wire staples fix the triangular silt barriers to the ground with wire staples .
the staples shall be made of numgage wire with legs at least num in num mm long .
num delivery storage and handling during shipment and storage protect the silt barrier with a heavyduty covering that will protect the barrier from sunlight mud dust dirt and debris .
num construction requirements num personnel general provisions num through num .
num equipment general provisions num through num .
num preparation general provisions num through num .
num fabrication general provisions num through num .
num construction install triangular silt barriers according to this specification as shown on the plans or as directed by the engineer .
num .
excavate a trench num to num in num to num mm deep using equipment such as a trenching machine or motor grader or if equipment can not be operated on site by hand .
num .
secure the edge of the fabric into the trench with wire staples .
num .
install the fabric in the trench so that num to num in num to num mm of fabric is against the side of the trench with num to num in num to num mm of fabric across the bottom in the upstream direction .
num .
backfill the trench and compact it so that no flow can pass under the barrier .
num .
where the individual sections of triangular silt barrier meet fix the fabric to the ground with wire staples at each joint location and at each end of the barrier .
the location and quantity of triangular silt barrier to be installed will be affected by the conditions that occur during the construction of the project .
the engineer may increase decrease or eliminate the quantity of triangular silt barrier .
do not consider these variations in quantity as alterations in the details of construction or a change in the character of the work .
triangular silt barrier may be substituted for baled straw .
num quality acceptance the engineer will reject the barrier at the time of installation if it has defects rips holes flaws deterioration or damage incurred during manufacture transportation or storage .
section numtriangular silt barrier num num contractor warranty and maintenance maintain the silt barrier until the project is accepted or until the silt barrier is removed and remove and dispose of silt accumulations .
maintenance and sediment removal is covered in section num .
remove and replace triangular silt barrier sections whenever effectiveness is reduced due to deterioration .
remove triangular silt barrier unless the engineer directs that it be retained .
barriers that have been removed will remain contractor property and may be used at other locations if its condition is acceptable to the engineer .
when the silt barrier is removed dress the area to give a pleasing appearance and seed and mulch the area according to section num .
num measurement the quantity of triangular silt barrier to be paid for will be the actual number of linear feet meters of triangular silt barrier measured in place from end to end of each separate installation which has been completed and accepted .
num limits general provisions num through num .
num payment triangular silt barrier measured as defined above will be paid for at the contract unit price bid per linear foot meter .
payment shall be full compensation for furnishing all materials erecting and maintaining the barrier removing accumulated silt except as described in subsection num for all dressing and grassing and for removing the barrier .
payment for this item will be made as follows num of the contract price bid per linear meter will be paid when each barrier is complete in place .
num will be paid at removal or acceptance .
payment will be made under item no .
num .
triangular silt barrier per linear foot meter num adjustments general provisions num through num .

num definitions qualified electrician either an electrician with a class ii license issued by the georgia state construction industry licensing board or an electrician who has completed an approved fouryear apprenticeship training program and is classified as a journeyman electrician .

section numcoarse aggregate num general description this section includes requirements for coarse aggregate .
all aggregate shall be the specified type class and grade and shall meet the requirements for the intended use .
num related references a .
standard specifications section numbituminous surface treatment b. referenced documents aashto astm t num t num t num t num t num c num e num g num section numcoarse aggregate num gdt num gdt num gdt num qpl num sop num num materials num coarse aggregate a .
requirements the contractor shall use the type group class and grade of coarse aggregate specified .
for coarse aggregate sources see qpl num .
num .
coarse aggregate types type characteristics crushed stone sound durable rock particles .
gravel sound durable rock without damaging coatings .
aircooled blast furnace slag sound durable particles with uniform density and quality or other slags that have a good service record .
dry slag shall weigh at least num lbft³ num kgm³ compacted and shall contain less than num glassy particles by weight .
do not use slag as aggregate for portland cement concrete .
synthetic aggregate sound durable expanded clay shale or other manufactured product .
num .
coarse aggregate groups a .
group i limestone dolomite marble or any combination thereof .
ensure group i aggregates meet the abrasion requirement for class a stone when used in portland cement concrete of any type or class .
b .
group ii slag gravel granitic and gneissic rocks quartzite synthetic aggregate or any combination thereof .
num .
classes aggregates are classified by physical properties that determine how they are used .
a .
do not blend aggregates that meet abrasion requirements with aggregates that do not meet requirements .
b .

soundness test coarse aggregate used in portland cement concrete bituminous surfaces bituminous bases aggregate bases or surface treatment with five alternations of the magnesium sulfate soundness test .
a .
use aggregate with a weight loss of less than num percent .
b .
the num percent soundness loss for a class cs concrete is waived if it has a numyear service record .
c. if the material meets all the requirements except for the num percent soundness requirement the material may be used in zones num and num see subsection num construction requirements under the following conditions num the aggregate in bituminous courses and in all types and classes of portland cement concrete construction except as stated in group i has a satisfactory fiveyear service record under similar service and exposure .
num the engineers investigation shows that it equals or exceeds the quality of approved aggregate in cases where the materials uniformity changes at the source or does not have a fiveyear service record .
num .
grades use coarse aggregate that is well graded within the limits and sizes specified in table num .
num .
detrimental substances a .
detrimental substances include shale weathered or decomposed rock friable particles or any substance that may be detrimental for the use intended .
b .
do not use any aggregate that can cause a deleterious reaction .
c. do not use aggregates that contain chrysotile defined as fibrous serpentinite as a temporary or permanent unbound surfacing for roads nor as stabilizer for soil used as subgrade base or surface course .

section numgeogrid materials num general description this specification includes requirements for geogrid used in reinforced slopes and mechanically stabilized embankment mse wall backfill .
num definitions astmamerican society for testing and materials grigeosynthetic research institute num related references a .
standard specifications section numcontrol of materials section nummechanically stabilized embankment retaining walls section nummechanically stabilized embankment retaining wallcontractor design b. referenced documents aashto task force num guidelines u. s. environmental protection agency method numchemical compatibility association of textile chemists and colorists method numsoil burial american associaltion of textile chemists and colorists method numpreparation of bacterial broth astm d num astm d num astm d num astm d num astm d num section numgeogrid materials num astm d num astm d num astm d num astm d num griggnum griggnum griggnuma or ggnumb griggnum num submittals supply certification from the manufacturer showing the physical properties of the material used and conformance with the specifications according to subsection num of the specifications .
provide evidence from the manufacturer that the geogrid has been used successfully in installations with similar environmental and project conditions .
obtain prior approval from the office of materials for all materials before use on construction .
submit product specifications and test results to the engineer for review and approval at least num days prior to intended use .
do not begin placement of geogrid until the test results have been reviewed and approved by the engineer .
num materials a .
requirements use geogrid that is free of defects punctures or flaws .
num .
geogrid for reinforced slopes use geogrid materials for reinforced slope construction that consist of the following either a biaxial or uniaxial grid of polymer tensile elements manufactured into a regular network with apertures of sufficient size to allow for soil interlock .
a commercially prepared material of high tenacity polyester high density polyethylene hdpe or polypropylene that is formed by stretching heat welding chemical welding knitting weaving or combinations of these methods .
adhere to the following additional requirements a .
long term design strengths num .
use geogrid that meets the minimum longterm design strengths tlt in the machine direction as indicated on the plans .
num .
provide to the engineer in writing the ultimate tensile strength of the grid tult to verify the calculation in obtaining the longterm design loads tlt .
these strengths are required for the project and are determined based on the aashto task force num guidelines which incorporates reduction factors to the ultimate strength of the geogrid for creep site damage and durability .
num .
calculate the longterm design strength using the following formula tlt tult x crc fc x fd where tlt longterm design loadlbft kgm section numgeogrid materials num tult geogrid ultimate tensile strengthlbft kgm crc creep reduction coefficient fc factor of safety to account for construction damage fd factor of safety to account for product durability b .
determine tult determine the tult based on wide strip tensile testing as noted in subsection num. c. determine reduction factors determine the reduction factors by the methods described in paragraphs a e as follows num creep a provide evidence from the manufacturer that the geogrid has been tested in laboratory creep tests according to the following criteria conducted for a minimum duration of num hours tests were made for a range of load levels including loads that the geogrid will be subjected to on the project .
b ensure these tests are conducted as specified in subsection num. c extrapolate the results extrapolated to a minimum design life of num years .
d determine the tension level at which the total strain of the geogrid is not expected to exceed num within the design life of num years designated tw .
e calculate the creep reduction factor as follows crc tw tult in the absence of test data use the following creep reduction factors for different polymers polymer type creep reduction coefficient polyester num polypropylene num polyamide num polyethylene num num construction damage a provide evidence from the manufacturer that the geogrid has been subjected to full scale construction damage tests using fill materials and construction procedures which are representative of those on the project .
b excavate and test the grid according to subsection num. c calculate the construction damage factor of safety using the following formula fc tult tc where fc the construction damage factor tc the ultimate strength of the excavated grid that has been subjected to construction damage tests .
tult geogrid ultimate tensile strengthlbft kgm section numgeogrid materials num d if construction damage tests have been made but with fills or construction procedures other than those represented on the project use a minimum value of fc of num .
use a lower value of fc only if substantiated with damage tests using fills and construction procedures specific to the project .
e in the absence of any construction damage tests use a fc value of num .
num product durability a provide evidence from the manufacturer that the geogrid has been subjected to a series of durability tests to examine the effects of chemical and biological exposure on the grid as described in the aashto task force num report .
b include the following in the durability studies effect on shortterm and longterm mechanical properties .
changes to the following reinforcement microstructure dimensions mass oxidation environmental stress cracking hydrolysis temperature plasticization surface micrology variations in the infrared spectrum analysis .
a full investigation into the synergetic effects of different environments particularly temperature .
subject the reinforcement to a working stress during the environmental test .
c ensure that geogrid used in the work has been subjected to the environmental conditioning as outlined by the following as a minimum u.s. environmental protection agency method num chemical compatibility .
association of textile chemists and colorists method num soil burial .
american association of textile chemists and colorists method num preparation of bacterial broth .
d investigate the full range of soil environments to which the reinforcements may be potentially exposed and shall include as a minimum ph in the range of num num num num astmdnum diesel oil astmdnum fungi and bacteria uv exposure num hrs astmdnum solvents and agents that are site specific .
in the performance of this testing the conditioning temperature is laboratory standard plus num times laboratory standard for the ph environments .
when no conditioning time period is given use num days .
extrapolate results from shortterm tests to the required design life of num years .
after the geogrid is subjected to these conditions test the geogrid according to subsection num and calculate the durability factor of safety by the following formula section numgeogrid materials num fd tult td where td the ultimate strength of the geogrid subjected to product durability tests .
the minimum allowable value of fd is num .
in the absence of any geogrid durability tests use a durability factor fd of num .
num .
pullout resistance a provide evidence from the manufacturer that the geogrid has been subjected to fullscale pullout tests using backfill materials representative of those on the project as described in the aashto task force num report .
b base pullout resistance for design on a maximum of elongation of the embedded geogrid of ¾ in num mm as measured at the leading edge of the compressive zone within the soil mass and not the ultimate pullout capacity .
c where insufficient data exists to evaluate the pullout resistance of geogrid as a function of soil type conduct pullout tests on a project specific basis until the engineering behavior of the soilreinforcement system is clearly defined .
d perform pullout using vertical stress variations sv and reinforcement element configurations simulating actual project conditions .
e perform pullout tests according to subsection num on samples with a minimum embedded length of num ft num mm .
perform the tests on samples with a minimum width of num foot num mm or a width equal to a num longitudinal grid element whichever is greater .
conduct the tests at num of num of numºc num c at constant strain rates of num in nummm per minute .
evaluate the pullout resistance by the following relation tp num tan p x sv x ls x fd where tp ultimate pullout capacity of tensile reinforcementlbft kgm sv vertical stresslb ftnum kgmnum ls total length of geogrid beyond failure planeft m p internal angle of friction of select backfill fd equivalent coefficient of direct sliding derived from pullout tests the equivalent coefficient of direct sliding fd may be related to the open area of the grid .
in the absence of product specific data tested with sitespecific granular backfill estimate the from the following preliminary analysis open area of grid direct sliding num more num num to num num num or less num section numgeogrid materials num ensure the pullout resistance tp meets the following minimum strength requirement tp fpo x tlt with a displacement less than or equal to ¾ in num mm where fpo factor of safety against pullout equal to num tlt longterm design loadlbft kgm num .
junction strength a ensure that the summation of the shear strength of the joints occurring in a num in num mm length of the grid sample is greater than the ultimate tensile strength of the element to which they are attached .
b if this condition is not met reduce the allowable reinforcement tension tw by the ratio of the shear strengths to the ultimate strength .
c determine the ultimate tensile strength according to subsection num and translate it into an ultimate strength per element by dividing the number of elements per foot meter of width .
d measure the junction strength according to subsection num .
num .

section numroadway materials num general description this section includes the requirements for the materials used in roadway construction .
num related references a .
standard specifications general provisions num through num .
b. referenced documents gdt num gdt num gdt num gdt num num materials num roadway materials a .
requirements do not use materials containing logs stumps sod weeds or other perishable matter .
num .
classes the materials are divided into six major classes .
classes i ii and iii are further subdivided and identified by description and physical property requirements specified in the table below and in table num .
classes iv v and vi are identified by descriptive requirements .
class i ianum and ianum medium to wellgraded sand or clayey sand .
ianum finegrained silty or clayey sand usually less dense than ianum or ianum .
these soils have an excellent bearing capacity .
class ii iibnum iibnum and iibnum medium to wellgraded sandy clays sandy silts and clays with some mica .
these soils generally have low volume change properties and good densities that serve well as subgrade material .
iibnum similar to iibnum iibnum and iibnum but generally contain more mica and are more sensitive to moisture .
the bearing value of these soils is less predictable .
the soils may or may not be satisfactory for subgrade material .
analyze file data or section numroadway materials num run laboratory andor field tests for class iibnum when considering it for a subgrade material .
class iii iiicnum iiicnum iiicnum and iiicnum medium to finegraded micaceous sandy silts micaceous clayey silts chert clays and shaly clays .
undesirable characteristics are high volume change properties andor low densities .
the bearing values are unpredictable .
the department recommends testing these materials in a laboratory where possible before use .
one exception is district num where chert clay soils are prevalent .
chert clay soils iiicnum with less than num passing the no .
num num mm sieve may be considered suitable for subgrade materials .
these soils are found generally in the northwest corner of the state in dade walker catoosa whitfield murray chattooga gordon and floyd counties .
class iv highly organic soils or peat muck and other unsatisfactory soils generally found in marshy or swampy areas .
class v shaly materials that are not only finely laminated but have detrimental weathering properties and tend to disintegrate .
class vi rock or boulders that can not be readily incorporated into the embankment by layer construction and that contain insufficient material to fill the interstices when they are placed .

num num mm sieve subclass no .
num num µm sieve passing no .

num num mm sieve may be considered suitable for subgrade material .

requirements num .
use topsoil or sandclay that is a natural or artificial mixture of clay or soil binder with sand or other aggregate .
do not use a mixture that contains substances detrimental to the material .
obtain the materials from sources approved by the engineer .
ensure that the aggregate retained on no .
num num mm sieve coarse aggregate is of hard durable particles .
num .
sand and binder use hard sharp durable siliceous particles .
use binder made from quality clay .
num .
oversize remove particles with diameters greater than num in num mm before depositing the topsoil or sandclay on the road .
remove particles with screens or grizzlies or by hand if few oversized pieces exist .
you may crush the oversized pieces and use them .
num .
topsoil use a topsoil that is a natural generally pebbly material occurring in shallow surface deposits on usually elevated areas .
num .
natural sandclay use a natural sandclay that is a mixture of natural material largely sand and clay in proper proportions occurring in deposits of considerable depth .
num .
artificial sandclay use an artificial sandclay that is largely a mixture of artificial sand and clay .
you may make the mixture by combining clay or soil binder and sand or aggregate in the proper proportions .
num .

stockpiles in all cases stockpile the end product so that the material will be blended before any of it is loaded and delivered to the job .
a .
make a stockpile big enough to uniformly blend the workable strata in the pit .
b .
the engineer will determine the minimum volume of the stockpile .
the engineer will also be the sole authority as to the quality and workability of the various strata occurring in the pit .
c. maintain the minimum volume of the stockpile until the suitable material in the pit has all been stockpiled or until the material remaining in the stockpile is enough to complete the operation as governed by haul limitations .

section numfiber stabilizing additives num general description this section covers the general requirements for fiber stabilizing additives incorporated into asphaltic concrete mixtures .
these fibers are used to stabilize the asphalt film surrounding aggregate particles to reduce draindown of the asphalt cement use cellulose or mineral fiber stabilizer listed on qpl num fiber stabilizing additives .
num related references a .
standard specifications general provisions num through num .
b. referenced documents aashto t num astm d num astm c num gdt num gdt num qpl num num materials use an approved mineral or cellulose fiber stabilizing additive currently listed in qpl num .
approved additives shall meet the requirements below .
dosage rates below are typical ranges .
use the dosage rate prescribed in the job mix formula as approved by the office of materials .
a .
requirements for all fiber types num .
use a fiber stabilizer of the type and properties appropriate to the plants metering and delivery system .
num .
when tested in a standard mixture according to gdt num the fiber stabilizing additive shall limit draindown to not more the num of the weight of the mixture .
for the purpose of evaluating these additives the following test conditions apply .
the mixture tested shall consist of a standard no .
num stone and num asphalt cement .
mixing and compaction temperatures for the test shall be as prescribed in aashto t num section num .
wet mixing time shall be num num seconds .
unseparated fibers determined by visual inspection of the mixture after the draindown test shall not exceed num of total fiber content .
section numfiber stabilizing additives num b. cellulose fibers add cellulose fibers at a dosage rate between num and num by weight of the total mix according to the approved job mix formula .
fiber properties shall be as follows ash content by astm d num num maximum nonvolatile content ph num to num moisture content num maximum c. cellulose pellets use cellulose fiber stabilizing additive in pellet form that meets the requirements of subsection num.a and subsection num.b .
use pellets that disperse sufficiently at mixing temperature to blend uniformly into the asphalt mixture .
use pellets that do not exceed num in num mm average pellet diameter .
pellets may contain binder ingredients such as asphalt cement wax or polymer .
do not use pellets if the binder ingredient exceeds num of the total weight of the pellets .
use binder that produces no measurable effect on the properties of the asphalt cement .
do not use fiber pellets which soften or clump together when stored at temperatures up to num numf num numc .
add approved palletized fiber stabilizing additive at a dosage rate between num and num by weight of the total mix according to the approved job mix formula established by the office of materials .
note if the binder material constitutes more than num of the pellet weight the dosage rate shall be based upon the net fiber content .
d. mineral fibers use mineral fibers made from virgin basalt diabase slag or other silicate rock .
add the fiber at a dosage rate prescribed in the approved job mix formula between num and num by weight of the total mix .
use approved mineral fiber from qpl num not exceeding num shot content in accordance with astm c num as tested according to gdt num e. materials warranty general provisions num through num .

num .
grade use the various grades of asphalt cement meeting the requirements shown in the test requirements for petroleum asphalt cements .
add styrenebutadienestyrene sbs or styrenebutadiene sb to neat asphalt to produce a binder meeting requirements for pg num when roadway adt is equal to or greater than num for stone matrix asphalt and porous european mix pem or open graded friction course ogfc mixtures .
styrene butadiene rubber sbs or crumb rubber modified pg num is an acceptable alternative to sbs or sb modified asphalt cement at contractors discretion when roadway adt is less than num provided the sbr or crumb rubber modified asphalt cement meets the tests requirements of pg num .
for sbr modified pg num or pg num to meet pg num use only sbr currently approved on qplnum georgias list of approved latex suppliers .
for crumb rubber modified pg num or pg num to meet pg num use num mesh size ambient or cryogenic ground tire rubber at minimum num of weight of total asphalt cement content .
ensure trans polyoctenamer is added at num of the weight of the crumb rubber to achieve better particle distribution .
varying percentage blends of crumb rubber and approved additives may be used at the discretion of the office of materials provided the end product meets all specified requirements of pgnum including phase angle .
ensure the end product is homogenous and shows no separation or coagulation .
percentage of ambient or cryogenic ground tire rubber is neat asphalt source dependent to meet specification requirements for pg num .
the maximum phase angle requirement is not applicable to the crumb rubber modified pg num incorporating num crumb rubber with approved additive equivalent to num of crumb rubber see notes f g i and j .

num section numdampproofing or waterproofing material num general description this section includes the requirements for material used as a mopping coat in dampproofing or as mopping cement for a waterproof membrane system .
num related references a .
standard specifications general provisions num through num .
b. referenced documents aashto m num aashto m num num materials num bituminous material for dampproofing or waterproofing a .
requirements use a bituminous material that contains a primer coat and a sealer or mopping coat .
num .
primer use a primer coat that meets the requirements of aashto m num .
num .
sealer or mopping coat use a coaltar pitch that meets the requirements of aashto m num .
num .
coaltar pitch types unless otherwise specified use pitch type i or type ii as defined below only when required by the contract .
use type i on vertical surfaces and type ii on flat surfaces .
a .
type i pitch a mopping coat for builtup roofs surfaced with slag or gravel .
if the roof has nails use the coat on inclines not exceeding num inft num mmnum mm .
if the roof does not have nails use the coat on inclines not exceeding num inft num mmnum mm .
a mopping coat for dampproofing or a plying cement for building a membrane system of waterproofing above ground level .
do not use this material if it will be exposed to temperatures over num f num c. note this type of coaltar pitch is suitable on railroad bridges tanks retaining walls culverts dams conduit etc .
b .
type ii pitch a mopping coat for dampproofing or a plying cement in building a membrane system of waterproofing below ground level .
use this material for roofs exposed to moderate temperatures during installation and service .
b .

section numhot mix asphaltic concrete mixtures num general description this specification includes the requirements for hot mix asphaltic concrete mixtures including opengraded surface mixtures ogfc and pem stone matrix asphalt mixtures sma superpave mixtures finegraded num mm mixtures num definitions the nominal maximum sieve size is one standard sieve size larger than the first sieve to retain more than ten percent of the aggregate per aashto rnum .
mixture types in this section are identified according to nominal maximum sieve size .
num related references a .
standard specifications section numhot mix asphaltic concrete construction section numcoarse aggregate section numaggregates for asphaltic concrete section numfiber stabilizing additives section numasphalt cement section numadmixtures section numlime section nummineral filler b. referenced documents aashto rnum aashto rnum aashto tnum aashto t num aashto t num aashto t num aashto t num aashto tnum aashto tnum sopnum section numhot mix asphaltic concrete mixtures num sopnum gdt num gdt num gdt num gdt num gdt num gdt num gdt num qpl num qpl num qpl num qpl num qpl num qpl num qpl num num materials a .
requirements use approved hot mix asphalt concrete mixtures that meet the following requirements num .
produce each asphalt mixture according to a department approved job mix formula and asphalt mix design see subsection num for submittal and approval of job mix formulas .
num .
ensure individual acceptance test results meet the mixture control tolerances specified in the appropriate table below subsections num through num .
num .
ensure the engineer approves all materials used to prepare and place the mixtures before incorporating them into the work .
use only the ingredients listed in the approved asphalt mix design and job mix formula .
for virgin aggregates use sources meeting the requirements of section num and are listed in qpl num or qpl num for mixes in which local sand is permitted use the approved sand source identified in the mix design .
for mixtures containing reclaimed asphalt pavement rap use only rap from the approved stockpile identified in the mix design .
use asphalt cement meeting the requirements of section num from a source listed in qpl num .
num .
obtain approved sma mix designs superpave mix designs and num mm mix designs from a mix design laboratory certified by the department .
obtain approved mix designs for types pem and ogfc mixtures from the departments office of materials and research which produces and furnishes these mix designs .
num .
ensure all sma mix designs are designed in accordance with gdtnum determining the design proportions of stone matrix asphalt mixtures .
sma mix designs shall be verified and approved by the department prior to use .
ensure that superpave and num mm mix designs are designed in accordance with sopnum control of superpave bituminous mixture designs and are approved by the department as provided therein .
ensure these mixes are designed by a laboratory and technician certified in accordance with sopnum certification of laboratories and personnel for design of sma and superpave asphalt mixtures .
num .
use only mixtures composed of the aggregate groups and blends indicated in the proposal and plans by their pay item designations defined as follows section numhot mix asphaltic concrete mixtures num pay item designation allowable aggregate groups group i or ii group i group ii or blend i group ii only group ii only blend i either num group ii material or a blend of group i and group ii .
do not use group i material for more than num by weight of the total aggregate nor more than num by weight of the coarse aggregate fraction .
num .
for patching or leveling use group i group ii or blend i .
mix types for patching and leveling are specified in subsection num.b .
num .
include lime hydrated lime from an approved source and meeting the requirements of section num in all paving courses except as otherwise provided in the contract .
for a list of approved sources of lime see qpl num. a .
add lime to each mixture at the rate prescribed in the approved mix design .
b .
ensure mix designs using only virgin aggregate include lime at a minimum rate of num of the total dry aggregate weight .
ensure mix designs using rap include lime at a minimum rate equal to num of the virgin aggregate fraction plus num of the aggregate in the rap fraction .
c. add more lime or add lime plus an approved heatstable antistripping additive that meets the requirements of section num if necessary to meet requirements for mixture properties and pursuant to an approved mix design .
however the department will not make additional payment for these materials .
for a list of sources of heat stable antistripping additives see qpl num. d. where specifically allowed in the contract on larp airport and parking lot projects an approved heatstable antistripping additive that meets the requirements of section num may be substituted for hydrated lime .
ensure the mix gradation is adjusted to replace the lime with an equivalent volume of fines passing the num mm sieve .
add heatstable antistripping additive at a minimum rate of num percent of the asphalt cement portion .
num .
use performance grade pg num or pg num asphalt cement in all mix designs and mixtures except as follows a .
the state bituminous construction engineer will determine the performance grade to be used based on table num binders selection guideline for reclaimed asphalt pavement rap mixtures aashto mnum and laboratory testing results as required in section num.b for mixtures containing num equivalent binder replacement for rapras mixtures .
b .
use only grade pg num excluding shoulder construction in the following mixes all sma num mm pem num mm and num mm ogfc num mm superpave on projects with adt greater than num and in all mixtures for which polymermodified asphalt is specified in the pay item .
num .
use of local sand is restricted as follows a .
do not place mixtures containing local sand on the traveled way of the mainline or ramps of the interstate system .
mixtures with local sand may be used for shoulder construction on these facilities .
b .
ensure local sand will not constitute more than num of the total aggregate weight of any mix design or production mix .
c. subject to the above limits num mm num mm and num mm superpave mix designs and num mm mix designs containing local sand may be used on projects with a current adt not exceeding num. d. num mm superpave mix designs containing not more than num local sand may be used on all facilities except the main line and ramps of the interstate system .
e. obtain local sand for use in asphalt mixtures from a source approved by the department .
f. approval of local sand sources the department will sample test and approve sources of local sand .
local sand shall not contain more than num clay by weight and shall be free of foreign substances roots twigs and other organic matter .
ensure sand is free of clay lumps as determined by aashto t num and shall have a sand equivalent value exceeding num as determined by gdt num .
section numhot mix asphaltic concrete mixtures num b .
fabrication num .
design procedures for all superpave and num mm mixes ensure conformance with the superpave system for volumetric design aashto t num and aashto rnum as adapted in sopnum .
ensure superpave mixes are designed at a design gyration number ndes of num gyrations and initial gyration number nini of num gyrations .
for num mm mixes ndes shall be num gyrations and nini shall be num gyrations .
opengraded mix designs will be designed in accordance with gdt num by the department .
in all cases the procedure for measuring maximum specific gravity gmm shall be aashto t num .
in addition to gradation and volumetric analysis mix designs shall include the following performance tests as applicable .
num .
performance test a. permeability test superpave and stone matrix mix designs shall include testing according to gdt num measurement of water permeability of compacted asphalt paving mixtures .
specimen air voids for this test shall be num num .
the average permeability of three specimens may not exceed num ft per day num numcm per sec .
b. moisture susceptibility test mix designs of all types except opengraded surface mixes shall include testing for moisture susceptibility according to gdt num .
specimen air voids for this test shall be num num for all mixes excluding stone matrix mixes .
specimen air voids for this test shall be num num for stone matrix mixes .
the minimum tensile splitting ratio is num except that a tensile splitting ratio of no less than num may be acceptable if all individual strength values exceed num psi num kpa .
average splitting strength of the three conditioned and three controlled samples shall be not less than num psi num kpa for either group .
retention of coating as determined by gdt num shall be not less than num. c. rutting susceptibility test mix designs of all types except opengraded surface mixes ogfc and pem and mixtures designed exclusively for trench widening shall include testing according to gdt num or aashto t num .
design limits for this test are as follows specimen air voids for this test shall be num num for all mix types .
testing temperature shall be numc numf for all mix types except num mm and num mm superpave mixes which shall be tested at numc numf .
maximum deformation shall be num mm for all mixes except num mm mix num mm type i and num mm type ii superpave mixes .
maximum deformation for the num mm type ii superpave mix shall be num mm at numc numf and num mm at numc numf for the num mm and num mm type i superpave mix .
d. fatigue testing the department may verify densegraded mix designs by fatigue testing according to aashto t num or other procedure approved by the department .
e. hamburg wheeltracking test the department may verify warm mix asphalt densegraded mix designs or mix designs incorporating polyphosphoric acid ppa modified binders by hamburg wheeltracking testing according to aashto t num .

standard specifications section numadmixtures b. referenced documents aashto m num aashto m num qpl num num materials num portland cement a .

num .
type use portland cement that meets the requirements in aashto m num .
portland cement types include use high early strength concrete remaining portland cement concrete portland cement types i or iii types i or ii portland cement a hydraulic cement produced by pulverizing clinker consisting essentially of hydraulic crystalline calcium silicates and usually containing one or more of the following water calcium sulfate up to num limestone and processing additions .
num .
ensure that the portland cement concrete meets the low alkali and the false set requirements of aashto m num .
num .
do not use cement that is damaged partially set lumpy or caked .
num .
mixing and storing do not mix or store different brands or types of cement in the same bin .
do not mix or store the same brand of cement from different mills in the same bin .

num fly ash raw or calcined natural pozzolan slag and microsilica a .
requirements num .
fly ash fly ash is finely divided residue from the combustion of ground or powdered coal that is transported from the boiler by flue gases .
use fly ash that meets the requirements of aashto m num class f or c and that are listed in qpl num .
num .
raw or calcined natural pozzolan this is a siliceous or siliceous and aluminous material .
use pozzolan that meets the requirements of aashto m num class n and that are listed in qpl num .
num .
granulated iron blastfurnace slag this is a glassy granular material formed when molten blastfurnace slag is rapidly chilled and then finely ground .
use slag that meets the requirements of aashto m num grade num or num and that are listed in qpl num .
num .
microsilica silica fume this is an amorphous material with high silica content and purity made as a byproduct of high purity quartz that is reduced with other ingredients in an electricarc furnace .
use microsilica that meets the requirements of aashto m num .
b .
fabrication general provisions num through num .
c. acceptance the engineer will select the laboratory tests for acceptance and project control .

num hotpoured joint sealers a .
requirements num .
type section numjoint fillers and sealers num use a hotpoured joint sealer that is a mixture of materials compatible with asphalt with or without rubber .
the sealer shall have the following characteristics forms a resilient and adhesive compound effectively seals joints and cracks in pavements against moisture during repeated cycles of expansion and contraction does not flow from the joint and can not be picked up by vehicle tires at an ambient temperature of num f num c num .
compound characteristics use a compound that has a uniform pouring consistency capable of completely filling joints without forming large air holes or discontinuities .
a .
do not pour if the compound temperature is above num f num c. b .
follow the pouring temperature and safe heating temperature set by the compound manufacturer for each lot or batch .
c. be sure the temperatures are shown on the label .
the safe heating temperature is defined as the highest temperature to which the sealing compound can be heated and still meet all the requirements .
num .
physical characteristics use a hotpoured joint sealer that has the following properties property required measurement penetration less than num in num mm .
flow less than num in num mm .
resilience minimum recovery of num .
bond to concrete num f num f num c num c the compound does not separate or have gaps within or between the compound and the blocks .
compatibility with asphaltic concrete adhesion does not fail .
oily exudate does not form at the interface between the sealing compound and the asphaltic concrete .
the sealant does not soften or have deleterious effects on the asphaltic concrete .
b .
fabrication general provisions num through num .
c. acceptance the department will test as follows test method hotpoured joint sealers gdt num d. materials warranty general provisions num through num .
num elastomeric polymer type joint compound a .
requirements num .
type section numjoint fillers and sealers num furnish elastomeric polymertype joint sealing compound in two componentsa base compound and a curing agent .
a .
base compound a gasolineresistant elastometric polymer modified with plasticizers activators and inert fillers .
b. curing agent a blend of accelerators and extenders .
num .
compound characteristics use a sealing compound that can be mixed to a homogenous consistency at the site and applied by an approved mechanical device or poured and troweled manually .
a .
if a compound is to be machinemixed and applied it shall have a minimum work life of num minutes at num ºf num ºf num ºc num ºc .
b .
if a compound is to be manually mixed and applied it shall have a minimum work life of num minutes at num ºf num ºf num ºc num ºc .
c. use a mixture that completely fills the joints without forming air holes or discontinuities when mixed according to the manufacturers instructions .
d. use a compound that is selfleveling when placed in the joint but that does not show appreciable flow or movement along a superelevated joint .
e. use material that does not soften or show any apparent defect after being immersed in water for num days .
f. use a material that forms a tackfree rubberlike compound that seals pavement or bridge joints within num hours of application .
num .
physical properties use material that has the following physical properties property required measurement cone penetration between num in num mm and num in num mm flow no appreciable flow resilience air and ovencured samples minimum recovery of num bond no cracks separation or other opening over num num in .

requirements num .
silicone furnish silicone sealant in a onepart or two part silicone formulation .
use sealant that is compatible with the surface to which it is applied .
do not use acidcure sealants on portland cement concrete .
a .
use silicone that meets the physical requirements in table num .
for a list of silicone joint sealant sources please see qpl num .
identify silicones as the following types num type aa one part low modulus nonsag silicone .
used to seal horizontal and vertical joints in portland cement concrete pavements and bridges .
tooling is required .
num type ba one part very low modulus selfleveling silicone .
used to seal horizontal joints in portland cement concrete pavements and bridges .
tooling is not normally required .
section numjoint fillers and sealers num num type ca one part ultralow modulus selfleveling silicone .
used to seal horizontal joints in portland cement concrete pavements and bridges and joints between portland cement concrete pavement and asphaltic concrete shoulders .
tooling is not normally required .
num type da two part ultralow modulus selfleveling rapid cure silicone .
used to seal horizontal joints in portland cement concrete pavements and bridges and joints between portland cement concrete pavement and asphaltic concrete shoulders .
tooling is not required .
b .
use silicone sealant evaluated by the national transportation product evaluation program ntpep .
c. use sealant that is compatible with the surface to which it is applied .
do not use acidcure sealants on portland cement concrete .
d. use silicone that meets the following physical requirements table numphysical requirements for silicone sealants type silicone a b c d tensile stress at num strain max .

bond breakers bond breakers shall be chemically inert and resistant to oils gasoline solvents and primer if one is required .
install silicone sealants over a bond breaker to prevent the sealant from bonding to the bottom of the joint .
a .
use bond breakers that are chemically inert and resistant to oils gasoline solvents and primer if one is required .
b .
do not use bond breaker that will stain or adhere to the sealant .
c. use either a backer rod or tape bond breaker .

num masonry stone a .
requirements num .
type use stone for rubble masonry that is sound durable and does not contain segregations seams cracks pyrite intrusions or other structural defects or imperfections that affect weather resistance .
a .
do not use stone with rounded worn or weathered surfaces .
exposed faces can not show scars caused by quarrying .
weathered stone will be rejected .
b .
ensure that the stone has no more than num percent wear and no more than num percent loss after the magnesium sulfate soundness test .
c. use stone that can be wrought truly to lines and surfaces curved or plain .
d. ensure that each stone is at least num in num mm thick and num ft num mm wide except for fill stones used in wall interiors .
b .
fabrication general provisions num through num .
c. acceptance test as follows test method percent wear aashto t num soundness aashto t num d. materials warranty general provisions num through num .
num mortar and grout a .
requirements num .
use mortar and grout that consists of fresh mixtures of one part portland or masonry cement and three parts mortar sand and water .
you may add hydrated lime when using portland cement in amounts not exceeding num percent of the weight of cement .
a .
cement use portland cement that meets the requirements of subsection num or masonry cement that meets the requirements of astm c num. b. mortar sand use mortar sand that meets the requirements of subsection num. c. mixing mix dry in a mixer or in a clean tight box until a uniform mixture is produced .
then add enough water to produce the desired consistency .
do not use mortar and grout that has been mixed for more than num minutes .
retempering of mortar is not permitted .
b .
fabrication general provisions num through num .
section nummasonry materials num c. acceptance general provisions num through num .
d. materials warranty general provisions num through num .

type use a surface coating material that is fine to heavytextured and forms a tough adhesive bond to the concrete .
for a list of sources see qpl num. a .
use material that has the following characteristics application rate num num ft²gal num num m²l without run or sag on vertical surfaces dry film thickness minimum num mils num mm at application rate of num ft²gal num m²l color lusterless gray that matches federal standard color no .
num unless specified otherwise on the plans b .
use grouttype coatings that meet the requirements of interim federal specification ttpnum .
c. use painttype coatings that meet the requirements of federal specification ttcnumb .
num .
classification classify special surface coatings as either class a or b with these compositional characteristics .
a .
class aacrylic polymer modified portland cement grout an adhesive grout of portland cement acrylic polymer modifiers masonry sand and water .
add acrylic polymer modifiers to the cement grout in the form of an emulsion .
b .
class borganic resin bindertype coating pigmented organic binders with suitable texturing agents .
further classify the coatings by solventthinner type and resin type .
num type numacrylic emulsion a pigmented num percent acrylic polymer with suitable texturing aggregate additions .
do not use polyvinyl acetate and styrene butadiene polymers as modifying agents .
num type numorganic solvent thinned vinyl tolueneacrylate copolymer pigmented binder in compatible organic solvents with suitable texturing aggregate additions .
use an emulsion polymerization process to form the resinous binder .

section numpolymer concrete num general description this section includes the requirements for polymer concrete .
num related references a .
standard specifications general provisions num through num .
b. referenced documents aashto t num astm c num or c num astm c num astm c num astm c num section numpolymer concrete num num materials num polymer concrete a .
requirements num .
type use a methyl methacrylate mma or polyester polymer concrete that bonds to the substrate with the manufacturers recommended primer .
a .
use a polymer concrete that combines a twocomponent solventfree resin and selected clean dry aggregate .
b .
use a primer that is a twocomponent system recommended by the polymer concrete manufacturer .
after mixing apply it with brushes or another suitable method .
c. use a primer that is tackfree within one hour of mixing .
d. before adding dry aggregate at the job site to increase yield get approval from the office of materials and research .
num .
physical characteristics use a polymer concrete similar in color to portland cement concrete .
a .
use a polymer that can be mixed and placed like portland cement concrete .
b .
ensure that the polymer concrete meets the following requirements characteristic requirement initial setting time final setting time num minutes minimum num minutes maximum flexural strength num psi num mpa minimum in numhours minimum compressive strength num f num f num c num c at compressive strengthpsi mpa num hours num hours num days air cure num days moist cure num psi num mpa num psi num mpa num psi num mpa num psi num mpa water absorption num maximum shrinkage num maximum shear bond strength num psi num mpa in num hrs .
minimum b .
fabrication num .
packaging and storage a .
package polymer concrete in strong moistureproof paper bags or other suitable containers capable of withstanding shipping normal handling and storage without breakage .
b .
clearly label each container of the components of the polymer concrete system with the following information component designation manufacturers batch number mixing instructions c. display potential hazards and precautions according to the federal hazardous products labeling act .
c. acceptance the tests below include procedures to create specimens for the shear bond strength test .
section numpolymer concrete num num .
when performing acceptance tests follow the mixing instructions of the manufacturer .
num .
aircure all test specimens except for the numday moistcure compressive strength cubes .
num .
test as follows test method setting time astm c num flexural strength aashto t num num x num x num in num x num x num mm specimens compressive strength astm c num or c num whichever is applicable shear bond strength see procedures below absorption astm c num shrinkage astm c num num .
shear bond strength procedures the shear bond strength in psi mpa equals the load in pounds newtons divided by the interfacial area of the patch in square inches square millimeters .
test as follows a .
cast a num x num x ½ in num x num x num mm polymer patch on an aircured num x num x num in num x num x num mm concrete mortar base .
b .
saw the base and polymer patch into num in num mm segments for testing .
c. use a holding device and plunger to apply a load at a rate of num in num mm per minute to the patch until failure occurs .
d. materials warranty use a polymer concrete with a minimum storage life of num months under storage conditions of num to num f num to num c and a maximum relative humidity of num percent .

num .

fabrication general provisions num through num .
c. acceptance num .
you may use pipe in construction supplied from plants operating on certified acceptance status without prior evaluation by lots .
num .
test any approved or untested material prior to use that has been directly exposed to sunlight for more than num months .
num .
pipe lengths that have developed bends that can not be sufficiently straightened will be rejected .
a. straightening of individual pipe lengths by force will be permitted provided that no stress cracking occurs in the process .
b .
any pipe length that develops stress cracks will be rejected .
num .
certification process a .
to qualify as an approved source the manufacturer must present the following num evidence that the manufacturer has an acceptable quality control procedure for raw materials and manufacturing processes num a yearly notarized certification stating that all pipe furnished is manufactured to meet this specification b .
the department will conduct random plant inspections and take random samples at the plant or at the project site for testing .
c. the department will remove plants from certified acceptance status when at any time they demonstrate inadequate quality control or noncompliance of the pipe material specifications .
d. materials warranty num .
store and use polyethylene tubing properly .
it will melt and burn when exposed to flame .
num .
this product is flexible thinwalled and will temporarily weaken when heated .
be careful to avoid crushing or stretching the pipe on hot days with bright sunlight .

num steelbolted couplings a .
requirements num .
coupling types use steelbolted couplings for joining all types of plain end pipe .
ensure the couplings have the following characteristics wedge gasket and flared sleeve one steel middle ring two steel followers two wedgeshaped rubbercompounded gaskets and steel bolts dimensions and type for the size and kind of pipe to be joined including reducers if required num .
middle rings a .
ensure middle rings size num in num mm through num in num mm are fabricated from tubing and coldformed to provide proper flare at each end and to receive the wedge portion of the gasket .
b .
ensure middle rings size num in num mm and larger are made from either bar or plateflashwelded coldformed coldexpanded beyond the yield point of the steel to size the ring and prooftest the weld .
c. airtest all welded rings to ensure the weld is porousfree .
d. use middle rings that have a bellowed portion between the flares provided for the gaskets to accommodate pipe deflection .
num .
followers a .
ensure the followers meet these requirements size fabrication num in num mm through num in num mm one piece steel forgings .
above num in num mm through num ¼ innum mm coldformed twopiece construction .
num ¼ innum mm through num in num mm hot forged from a single piece circular plate water quenched after forging for maximum strength .
above num in num mm use a special contoured mill section circlerolled flashwelded and coldexpanded beyond the yield point of the steel to size the ring and prooftest the weld .
all followers have solid formed gasket recess free of seams or breaks to confine the gasket .
num .
gaskets use gaskets meeting the requirements of astm d num numaanumzbnum with the following exceptions color jet black surface nonblooming shore a durometer hardness num num tensile strength num psi num mpa minimum elongation num minimum section numpipe appurtenances num a .
use a rubber compound that will not deteriorate from age or exposure to air under normal storage or use conditions .
use natural or synthetic rubber that does not contain reclaimed rubber .
b .
use gaskets immune to impurities such as odorants liquid hydrocarbons carbon dioxide and water normally found in natural gas .
c. to electrically bond the pipe ends to the center ring make a permanent bond from material that can not corrode or deteriorate and is molded into the tip of the gasket .
num .
bolts use bolts that have elliptical necks and track heads .
align the elliptical neck and the elliptical hole in the follower so the bolt will not turn .
a .
ensure the shanks of the bolts have enough threads to compress the gasket .
b .
submit to the engineer the manufacturers recommended torque for tightening the bolts .
num .
coating a .
unless otherwise specified coat all metal parts in the shop to protect them during shipping and storage .
b .
after installation apply a coat of coaltar enamel to the coupling and uncoated ends of the pipe according to awwa m num .
num .
certification submit a certification from the pipe gasket or joint manufacturer to the engineer according to subsection num materials certification .
the certificate shall describe the physical properties of the rubber gasket and show the results on hydrostatic tests of the gasket and pipe used in the work .
b .
fabrication general provisions num through num .
c. acceptance the department will accept the material based on the certification .

num bituminous plastic cement a .
requirements num .
type use a bituminous compound composed of steamrefined petroleum asphalt or refined coal tar that is dissolved in a suitable solvent and stiffened with a mineral filler with short mineral fibers .
a .
ensure the material is smooth and uniform not thick livered or separating to a degree that it can not be remixed by stirring .
b .
ensure the material can be applied with a trowel putty knife or caulking gun without pulling or drawing and has good adhesive and cohesive properties when applied to joint surfaces .
c. you may apply the material cold to seal the joints of bellandspigot or tongueandgroove storm or culvert pipe .
d. ensure the bituminous plastic cement sets to a tough plastic coating without blistering when applied num to num in num to num mm thick on a tinned metal panel and cured at room temperature for num hours .
e. use bituminous plastic cement with these characteristics minimum maximum grease cone penetration num num weight lbsgal kgl num num nonvolatile percent num ash by ignition percent by weight num num num .

section nummiscellaneous steel materials num general description this section includes the requirements for miscellaneous materials such as steel bolts nuts and washers section nummiscellaneous steel materials num anchor bolts nuts and washers high tensile strength bolts nuts and washers corrugated steel plank for bridges steel grid for bridge floors num related references a .
standard specifications section numcontrol of materials b. referenced documents astm a numa numm a numma numm a numa numm a numa numm a numa numm a numa numm a numa numm a numa numm a numa numm b num e num f num f numm f num f numm f num recommended practice enum ansi b numm aashto m num num materials num steel bolts nuts and washers a .
requirements num .
bolts and nuts a .

b .
ensure all threads meet the requirements of the latest issue of ansi b numb numm .
c. use bolts that have class numa numh threads .
d. use nuts that have class num b numg threads .
e. ensure bolts that transmit shear are threaded so that no more than one thread will be within the grip of the metal .
f. use bolts long enough to extend entirely through the nut but no more than num in num mm beyond them .
num .

num .
fastener assemblies provide the office of materials and research at least three samples per lot of each material type furnished to project .
num .
certification test reports supply certifications on each item according to subsection num materials certification .
include on all certifications the item specification number type or grade finish and manufacturers productmarking symbol .
also supply the required mill test reports manufacturer certified test reports and distributor certified test reports with each shipment as follows a .
mill test reports mtr provide an mtr for all mill steel used to manufacture bolts nuts and washers .
indicate where the material was melted and manufactured .
b .
manufacturer certified test reports mctr supply the mctr to the department from the manufacturer of the bolts nuts or washers .
each mctr shall num show relevant information required by astm a num a numm or astm a num a numm and this specification including test results for any required coating .
num include the lot number and location where the bolts nuts or washers were manufactured .
num if the manufacturer furnished the entire assembly bolts nuts and washers have the manufacturer perform the rotational capacity tests .
num furnish the results and when and where all testing was performed .
c. distributor certified test reports dctr if a distributor purchases the various assembly components from different manufacturers the distributor may run the rotationalcapacity test in lieu of a manufacturer .
in this case show test results manufacturers component lot numbers and assigned rotational capacity lot numbers for each combination on the dctr .
d. the distributor is responsible for furnishing the required mtr mctr and dctr with each shipment .
b .
fabrication num .
bolts a .
if coating astm a num a numm bolts with zinc use either the hotdip or mechanically deposited process .
b .
do not hotdip or electroplate astm a num a numm bolts with any metallic coating .
the bolts become brittle in hydrogen and subsequently crack due to stress corrosion and delayed brittle failure .
c. apply these changes to astm a num a numm andor astm a num a numm for bolts num test astm a num a numm galvanized bolts for embrittlement according to astm f numf numm section num .
num perform proof load tests astm f numf num method num for all astm a num a numm and astm a num a numm bolts .
num .
nuts a. lubricate galvanized nuts with a lubricant that is clean and dry to the touch .
use a lubricant that has a color that contrasts with the zinc coating so that you can obviously see the coating at the job site .
b .
perform proof load tests for all nuts plain and zinc coated using the method described in astm f numf numm section num. c. if you use the nuts with galvanized bolts run the proof load test after the nut is galvanized overtapped and lubricated .
num .
fastener assemblies bolt nut and washer a .
unless otherwise approved by the engineer coat the assemblies with a zinc coating according to astm a numa numm .
b .
take coating thickness measurements on the wrench flats .
section nummiscellaneous steel materials num c. no single spot coating thickness measurement shall be less than the required individual specimen value shown on table num of astm a numa numm when taken according to astm recommended practice e num .
c. acceptance num .
fastener assemblies bolt nut and washer a .
take coating thickness measurements on the wrench flats according to astm recommended practice e num. b .
ensure no single coating thickness measurement is less than the required individual specimen value shown on table num of astm a numa numm .
num .
hardness test perform hardness tests on galvanized components after galvanizing the item and removing the coating .
num .
rotational capacity test rotational capacity tests are required on all black or galvanized after galvanizing assemblies prior to shipping .
the following directions are for department personnel a .
test each combination of bolt production lot nut lot and washer lot as an assembly .
b .
the project engineer may require additional rotationalcapacity tests on assemblies covered by subsections num.c.num.b.num and num.c.num.b.num .
num .
rotational capacity test bolts too short to fit in tension calibrator a .
equipment required calibrated manual torque wrench and a numft num mm long wrench .
spacers andor washers with holes that do not exceed the bolt diameter by num in num mm for bolts equal to or less than num inch num mm in diameter .
the hole size for larger bolts shall not exceed the bolt diameter by num in num mm .
steel section with holes to match bolt sizes .
note use a plate thick enough to accomplish step num in the procedure without spacers .
however spacers are acceptable .
b .
procedure num mark off a vertical line and lines onethird of a turn num degrees half of a turn num degrees and twothirds of a turn num degrees from vertical in a clockwise direction on the plate .
num measure the bolt length the distance from the underside of the bolt head to the end of the bolt .
num install a nut on the bolt and measure the stickout of the bolt when three to five full threads of the bolt are located between the bearing face of the nut and the bolt head .
num install the bolt in the appropriate size hole and if necessary install the required number of spacers to produce the thread stickout measured in step num always use at least one washer under the nut .
num snug the nut with the hand wrench .
snug should be the normal effort applied to a num in num mm long wrench .
do not exceed num percent of the torque determined in step num .
num align the nut with the vertical num degree stripe on the test frame plate .
this is for reference after you rotate the nut during testing .
num tighten the bolt by turning the nut with the torque wrench to the rotation in the table .
bolt length step num num bolt dia .
or less num to num bolt dia .
more than num bolt dia .
required rotation num num num use a second wrench to prevent the bolt from turning .
num measure and record the torque required to reach this rotation .
measure torque with the nut in motion .
ensure the torque in footpounds newtonmeters does not exceed the values in the table .
reject any assemblies that exceed the listed torques .

in mm astm a numa numm astm a num a numm num mnum num num num num num mnum num num num num num mnum num num num num num mnum num num num num num mnum num num num num num mnum num num num num num mnum num num num num num num num num num num num continue tightening the nut as follows bolt length step num num bolt dia .
or less num to num bolt dia .
more than num bolt dia .
required rotation num num num num measure the rotation from the initial marking in step num .
num loosen and remove the nut and examine the bolt and nut threads .
reject any assembly that shows evidence of thread shear stripping or torsional failure .
note reject any assemblies that fracture or are stripped before reaching the required rotation .
num .
rotational capacity test long bolts in tension calibrator a .
equipment required calibrated measuring device to measure tension for the bolts .

calibrated manual torque wrench .
spacers andor washers meeting the requirements of subsection num.c.num.a bullet num .
steel section to mount the bolt calibrator .
b .
procedure num measure the bolt length the distance from the underside of the bolt head to the end of the bolt .
num put the nut on the bolt and measure the stickout of the bolt when three to five full threads of the bolt show between the bearing face of the nut and the bolt head .
num install the bolt in the tension calibrator .
if necessary install the required number of spacers to produce the thread stickout measured in step num always use at least one washer under the nut .
num tighten the bolt by turning the nut with a hand wrench to the snug tensions listed below num num kips num num kn .

d. materials warranty num .
ship bolts nuts and washers from each rotationalcapacity lot in the same container .
a .
if shipping only one production lot number for each size nut and washer you may ship the nuts and washers in the same container .
b .
permanently mark each container with the rotationalcapacity lot number so that identification will be possible at any stage before installation .
num .
black bolts nuts and washers must be oily to the touch when installed .
clean and relubricate weathered or rusted bolts nuts and washers before installing them .
num .
improperly stored galvanized assemblies will develop white rust .
clean and relubricate as in subsection num.b.num.a any bolts nuts and washers that show evidence of white rust .

num dowel bars a .
requirements type use dowel bars for concrete pavement that are plain round steel bars that meet or exceed the tensile requirements of table numtensile requirements for deformed bars astm a num a numm grade num num .
b .
fabrication coat dowel bars with either high density polyethylene or epoxy as follows num .
high density polyethylene use polyethylene with the following characteristics thickness num to num mils num to num mm texture smooth and dense enough to provide adequate bond breaking characteristics undercoating adhesive modified rubber blend num to num mils num to num mm thick ensure that the undercoating retains its elasticity and effectively seals small cuts or abrasions from moisture migrating under the polyethylene plastic outer coating .
num .
epoxy prepare the dowels for coating select the epoxy material apply the epoxy and sample and test the properties of coated bars according to the requirements of section num. a .
apply a uniform smooth coating to the bars that results in a film num mils num mils nummm num mm thick after curing .
b .
do not coat the cut ends .
c. handle the coated dowels carefully to prevent damage to the coating or bar .
however bars can be welded through the epoxy to one side of the supportive basket .
section numreinforcement and tensioning steel num c. acceptance the department will accept the steel based on the results of the tests made by the department or on the certification of the manufacturer .
