num related references a .
standard specifications section numpreservative treatment of timber products b. referenced documents ansi num national electrical safety code national institute of standards and technology qpl num section numpiling and round timber num num materials a .
definition and limitation of defects decay disintegration of the wood substance due to wooddestroying fungi .
the words dote and rot mean the same as decay .
red heart is a form of decay .
compression wood an abnormal dense hard growth frequently occurring on the underside of limbs and leaning trunks of coniferous trees .
it is characterized by very wide and eccentric annual growth rings and includes what appears to be an exceptional proportion of summerwood growth .
the contrast in color between springwood and summerwood however is usually less in compression wood than in normal wood .
turpentine butt a scar caused from bleeding the trees to obtain turpentine .
scar a damaged surface caused from injury to the tree during growth .
sweep deviation of a piece or stick from a straight line measured from the center of one end to the center of the other end .
a straight line from the center of the butt to the center of the tip shall lie entirely within the body of the pile .
short crook a crook in which the direction of the piece or stick changes in a very short distance measured lengthwise .
burst check a crack approximately at right angles to the annual rings usually radial cracks in sticks from the center or from near the center to the outside or a combination of this crack and a ring shake caused through either seasoning exposure to high temperature or the process of preservative treatment .
unsound knot a knot solid across the face but containing incipient decay .
cluster knot two or more knots grouped together the fibers of the wood being deflected around the entire unit .
a group of single knots with fibers deflected around each knot separately is not a cluster even though the knots may be close together .
punk knot a fungus decay that extends from the interior of the piece of pile to the outside which when prodded is usually found to contain a snufflike substance .
ring knots three or more knots appearing in the same line of circumference or any foot of length .
num timber piles a .
requirements num .
use round timber piles of any species of wood that will withstand driving and support the load specified .
use plants listed on qpl num .
num .
soundness use piles of sound wood free from decay red heart or insect attack .
a. cedar and cypress the butt ends may have a pipe or stump rot hole not more than num in num mm in diameter .
cypress piles may have peck aggregating not more than num in num mm in diameter .
b .
southern pine piles may have unsound knots less than half the permitted size of a sound knot providing that the unsoundness does not extend more than num in num mm deep and that the adjacent areas of the trunk are not affected .
num .
density a .
all piles shall be dense with at least num annual rings per num in num mm and num in num mm or more of summerwood the darker harder portion of the annual ring as measured over the outer num in num mm of butt diameter on a radial line from the pith .
the contrast in color between summerwood and springwood shall be sharp and the summerwood shall be darker in color .
section numpiling and round timber num b. piles excluded by the above rule may be accepted provided they have at least four annual rings per num in num mm and num or more summerwood as measured over the outer num in num mm of butt diameter on a radial line from the pith .
num .
knots a .
sound knots for piles num ft num m long or less and in num of the length of piles over num ft num m measured from the butt sound knots less than num in num mm or num the diameter of the pile whichever is smaller .
for the top num length of piles over num ft num m long sound knots less than num in num mm or num the diameter of the pile whichever is smaller the size of a knot shall be its diameter measured at right angles to the length of the pile .
b. unsound knots are not permitted except in southern pine piles as specified in subsection num.a.num.b .
c. the sum of sizes of all knots in any num in num mm of the pile shall not exceed twice the size of the largest permitted single knot .
num .
holes allow holes that average less than num inch num mm in diameter if the sum of the average diameter of all holes in any num ft² numm² of pile surface is less than num in num mm .
num .
splits and shakes splits shall not be longer than the butt diameter of the pile .
the length of any shake or combination of shakes in the outer half of the radius of butt of the pile when measured along the curve of the annual ring shall not exceed num the circumference of the butt of the pile .
num .
sapwood piles to be treated with preservative shall have at least num in num mm of sapwood at the butt end .
num .
heartwood a .
in untreated piles for use in exposed work the diameter of the heartwood at the butt shall be at least num of the diameter of the pile at the butt .
b .
if high heartwood content is required for untreated foundation piles the plans will specify the ratio of heartwood to total diameter .
num .
peeling a. peel piles by removing all of the outer bark and at least num percent of the inner bark well distributed over the surface of the pile .
b .
if piles will be treated with preservative do not leave inner bark wider than num in num mm .
c. do not remove more than three annual rings of the solid wood .
num .
cutting and trimming a .
saw butts and tips square with the axis of the pile .
b .
trim or smoothly cut all knots and limbs flush with the surface of the pile or the surface of the swell surrounding the knot .
num .
straightness in general a straight line from the center of the butt to the center of the tip shall lie entirely within the body of the pile .
if specified the department can accept long piles for foundations but not for trestles if the straight line lies partly outside the body of the pile .
the maximum distance between the line and the pile shall not exceed num percent of the length of the pile or num in num mm whichever is smaller .
num .
taper cut piles above the butt swell so it has a continuous taper from the point of butt measurement to the tip .
section numpiling and round timber num num .
twist of grain do not allow spiral grain to exceed num degrees of twist when measured over any num ft num m section of the pile .
num .
limits of defects a. piles shall not have short crooks that deviate more than num in num mm from straightness in any num ft num m length .
b .
burst checks in piles shall be less than num in num mm wide measured at the outside and shall not extend over num in num mm long .
num .
circumferences diameters and lengths a .
the circumferences of piles measured under the bark shall have the minimum and maximum values in table num metric table num for the class specified .
no more than num percent of the piles in any shipment may have circumferences num in num mm less than the tabulated minimum values .
note requirements for tip circumference of piles that are longer than the required length may be applied at the tip end of the required length .
b .
the ratio of the maximum to the minimum diameter at the butt of any pile shall not exceed num. c. individual piles may vary from the length specified by num in num mm in piles shorter than num ft num m and num ft num mm in piles num ft num m or longer .
d. the average length of all piles of a specified length in each lot shall not be less than the length specified .

branding and inspection a .
ensure the pile length and the diameter of the butt and tip are branded in the butts of the piles .
b. legibly brand the preliminary inspection date in the tips .
b .
fabrication seasoning and preservative treatment where required season and treat according to section num .
c. acceptance the department will reject the pile based on any of the following defects decay deep scars unsound knots punk knots ring knots cluster knots compression wood if readily identifiable based on ordinary visual inspection the department may accept piles with sound turpentine scars undamaged by insects provided they meet all other requirements .

section numwood posts and bracing num general description this section includes the requirements for wood fence posts and bracing and wood sign posts .
num related references a .
standard specifications section numguard rail components section numpreservative treatment of timber products b. referenced documents astm a numm qpl num num materials num wood fence posts and bracing a .
requirements num .
type use southern pine for wood posts and bracing .
use the dimensions specified on the plans .
num .
physical characteristics use posts and bracing that have the following characteristics be round or sawed but all posts on a single project shall be the same .
be cut from sound and solid trees and contain no unsound knots .
accept sound knots if the diameter of the knot does not exceed num of the diameter of the piece at the point where it occurs .
be free from decayed wood rot and red heart and a ring shake and season checks that penetrate at any point more than num the diameter of the piece or are greater than num in num mm wide .
show at least four annual rings per num in num mm and at least num summerwood unless using southern pine veneer cores .
have no short or reverse bends .
num .
draw a line from the center of the top to the center of the butt .
the line shall not fall outside the body of the post nor be more than num in num mm from the geometric center of the post at any point .
section numwood posts and bracing num num .
the maximum allowable change in diameter of the post shall not exceed num in num mm in num ft num m. num .
accessories use metal caps to cover the tops of the posts .
use caps that are at least num in num mm thick .
use material that is aluminum or galvanized steel with num ozft² num gm² coating according to astm a numm .
use caps only when required by the plans .
b .

remove all bark and inner skin .
num .

for posts that will be driven you may make the butt end pointed before treatment .

num section numpreservative treatment of timber products num general description this section includes the requirements for applying preservatives conditioning treating inspecting marking testing and documenting the necessary information for treated timber used in department work .
num related references a .
standard specifications general provisions num through num .
b. referenced documents american wood preservers association awpa cnum wood for highway construction preservative treatment by pressure method awpa cnum awpa mnum awpa mnum awpa pnum aashto m num qpl num num materials num conditioning and preservative treatment a .
requirements num .
condition and preservative treat all timber products to meet the requirements of american wood preservers association awpa standard cnum wood for highway constructionpreservative treatment by pressure method except as described in this section .
num .
treatment plants ensure treatment plants comply with quality control procedures in awpa mnum .
a .
to expedite the work a commercial inspection agency approved by the department will inspect and test all treated timber products including any preservative treatment at the treatment plant before it is delivered to the project .
the treament plant shall bear all the cost associated with the inspection and test .
b .
before requesting an inspection the authorities of the treatment plant shall acquaint themselves with the timber specification requirements and shall segregate the material to be inspected for department work from other stock .
num .
preservatives use preservatives that meet the requirements in the awpa standard unless otherwise specified in the plans or the specifications .
a .
you may select one of three preservatives creosote pentachlorophenol chromated copper arsenate cca from the materials and usage table in awpa cnum .
b .
ensure pentachlorophenol solutions have at least num percent pentachlorophenol by weight dissolved in the petroleum solvents specified or pentachlorophenol in awpa pnum type a .
section numpreservative treatment of timber products num b .
fabrication num .
as practicable cut frame and bore timber before treatment .
num .
condition the timber first .
for southern pine species use the following treatment pentapetroleum dry in kiln to num average moisture content or less or condition in steam chromated copper arsenate cca dry in kiln to num average moisture content or less note do not heat the wood in the preservative and do not use boulton drying .
num .
preservative penetration ensure the preservative penetrates at least num in num mm or num percent of the sapwood for all lumber timber wood fence posts and ties in contact with the ground .
a .
ensure lumber timber and ties that do not contact the ground meet awpa cnum requirements .
b .
ensure preservative penetrates all other materials piles and poles according to applicable awpa requirements .
num .
preservative retention treat guard rail posts and offset blocks with pentachlorophenol or cca with a minimum num lbft³ num kg m³ retained in the outer num in num mm as required in awpa cnum and cnum .
num .
retreatment you may retreat a charge of material or a portion of it if the initial treatment does not meet requirements for retention penetration or appearance .
the department will allow only one retreatment .
note the department will reject any damage due to retreatment .
num .
conditioning after treatment a .
condition material that is dustfree .
b .
for lumber or timber that is treated with waterborne preservative and is to be painted dry by air kiln or some method of artificial conditioning to a moisture content of not more than num percent of the weight of the ovendry wood .
c. protect the treated lumber from the elements with a prime coat of paint or other approved means .
d. ensure the moisture content does not rise above num percent before applying the first coat of paint .
e. dry material treated with waterborne preservative that will not be painted to surface dryness in air or otherwise before installing it .
c. acceptance num .
inspection the department will sample and test preservatives according to the requirements of aashto m num .
note check qpl num for preapproved manufacturers that supply material compliant with this specification .
a .
the department will determine the level of preservative retention by testing the num to num in num to num mm assay zone .
b .
unless otherwise provided an approved commercial inspection agency will inspect treated timber products according to awpa mnum .
c. the inspector will test before during and after treating .
num .
marking section numpreservative treatment of timber products num the inspector will mark each acceptable piece with a hammer stamp before and after treatment .
a .
stamp only num percent of the offset blocks after treatment .
b .
ensure that both inspection stamps identify the inspector .
ensure that the beforetreatment stamp is clearly distinguished from the aftertreatment stamp .
num .
reporting the inspector from an approved commercial inspection agency shall a .
prepare reports of the treating process and results of the inspection that confirm treatment was completed according to these specifications .
b. furnish these reports to the office of materials and research .
c. report according to awpa mnum .
d. get a shipping report from the treatment plant showing the project number purchaser sizes and amounts of materials and preservative type for each shipment for department work .
e. furnish the shipment report and the treatment report to the office of materials and research .
d. materials warranty num .
retest treated material that has been in stock for two years before using .
num .
the department will reject any materials that fail to meet specifications unless they are retreated to meet all applicable requirements .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num general description this section includes the following requirements for precastprestressed concrete bridge members and piling manufacturing inspecting testing marking painting rubbing as specified plant handling storing shipping the term precastprestressed concrete is referred to as prestressed concrete in the rest of this section .
num related references a .
standard specifications section numcontrol of materials section numfield laboratory building section numconcrete structures section numreinforcement steel section numepoxy coated steel reinforcement section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num section numfine aggregates section numportland cement section numadmixtures section numreinforcement and tensioning steel section numbronze bushings bearings and expansion plates section numpaint section numelastomeric bearing pads section numepoxy resin adhesives b. referenced documents aashto m num aashto m num aashto m num aashto t num aashto t num astm a numa numm astm a numa numm astm a num astm a num astm a num aashto specification for highway bridges laboratory sopnum standard operating procedures for precastprestressed concrete qpl num gdt num num materials use materials that meet the specifications as follows material section concrete class aaa except as noted num steel bars for reinforcement num pretensioning steel wire strand num posttensioning steel wire num posttensioning steel bars num plain steel barsthreaded ends num portland cement num fine aggregate for mortar num aluminum powder num section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num selflubricating bronze bearing and expansion plates and bushings num primer coats num elastomeric pads num epoxy resin adhesive num microsilica silica fume num note do not use accelerators numhour accelerated strength concrete that contain chlorides in any prestressed concrete .
num prestressed concrete bridge members a .
requirements num .
portland cement use type i type ii or type iii cement that meets requirements of aashto m num for low alkali cement .
a .
use type ii cement in concrete to cast pile for specific locations noted on the plans .
num .
coarse aggregate a .
use the size specified and approved for prestressed concrete products .
b .
do not use unconsolidated limerock coarse aggregate in prestressed concrete piling or in any structure that has direct contact with water .
num .
microsilica silica fume the department may approve silica fume as an additive to concrete .
if approved add the silica fume at a rate not to exceed num percent of the cement content .
num .
epoxycoated reinforcement steel and wire if top steel mat of the bridge deck is epoxycoated the shear steel in the prestressed concrete beams will be epoxy coated in accordance with section num .
num .
welded wire fabric use welded wire fabric that meets the following requirements a .
use smooth wire fabric that meets the material requirements of aashto m num astm a num and this section .
b .
use deformed wire fabric that meets the requirements of aashto m num astm a num and this section .
num .
pretensioning steel wire strand use strands that meet all the requirements of astm a num grade num .
num .
slump limitation ensure the slump meets subsection num.a table num concrete mix table except when type f high range water reducers hrwr are added .
with hrwr you may increase the slump value from num in to num in num mm to num mm with a maximum slump value not to exceed num in num mm provided the concrete mix does not segregate .
num .
facilities and equipment plans facilities are approved according to laboratory sopnum standard operating procedures for precastprestressed concrete .
see qpl num for a list of approved facilities .
submit a complete set of plans and an itemized equipment list of the prestressing facilities to the engineer .
a .
for established plants already approved by the department the department will send a written notice about approval .
the plant need not comply with the requirements concerning plans and equipment listing .
b .
the department may withdraw the waiver at its discretion if the plant changes the facilities equipment production methods types of products or for any other reason .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num b .
fabrication num .
general plant requirements furnish erection drawings to the engineer that show the placement of superstructure units especially when the units are not interchangeable with respect to transverse placement within a span or with respect to the reversal of ends within a span .
num .
manufacturing facilities and equipment ensure that the prestressed concrete bridge members are made at a plant that has as a minimum the facilities and equipment specified as follows a .
do not start manufacturing until the engineer approves the facilities and equipment .
note regardless of approval the contractor is responsible for the facilities performance and obtaining additional equipment as needed .
b .
beds construct beds for casting prestressed concrete of concrete these shall be level or on a grade acceptable to the engineer .
c. anchorages design and construct anchorages so they will not yield under num percent of the maximum design load .
d. forms construct steel side and bottom forms unless the department allows other materials .
num design the forms so the bridge members will be well within the tolerances specified in subsection num.b.num .
num anchor the forms to prevent movement .
e. stressing equipment num jacks use jacks in good repair that do not leak .
calibrate them with the actual gauge or gauges that you will be using .
you may use pressure gauges load cells or dynamometers .
ensure all jack systems have devices that prevent the gauge pointer from fluctuating .
num calibration calibrate all devices to a reading accuracy of num percent within the proposed stressing range .
use an approved testing laboratory to calibrate the devices .
have the laboratory furnish at least five copies of the calibration chart for each device to the engineer .
recalibrate all stressing systems at least every num months and as required by the engineer .
use gauges that you can read from num ft num m and have a capacity of twice the maximum load .
f. elongation measurement use a system approved by the engineer and isolated from any movement in the bed or anchorages .
g. curing systems equipment use one of the curing methods listed below .
do not use curing compounds on prestressed concrete units unless the engineer gives written permission .
num water curing use equipment that consists of a clean nondeleterious water source a method of application and enough burlap or other means of moisture retention that will keep all surfaces of the concrete wet during the curing cycle except those in contact with the forms .
num steam curing use the following minimum basic equipment an enclosure tight enough to maintain a uniform atmospheric temperature around the concrete units .
a steam system that distributes live steam uniformly through nozzles capable of maintaining a temperature of at least num ºf num ºc in all weather .
do not eject steam directly against concrete or forms .
a controlling device installed in the steam line that helps maintain a constant temperature .
a recording thermometer for each num ft num m of bed length .
num heated forms uniformly heat the forms with a recirculating system that distributes the heat evenly .
use a system that includes a means of retaining moisture on concrete surfaces except those in contact with the forms .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num a recording thermometer for each num ft num m of bed length .
a weathertight covering for each bed to ensure uniform heating throughout the bed .
h. vibrators use internal vibrators with at least num impulses per minute .
ensure the vibrator heads are small enough to reach through the prestressing and reinforcing steel to all portions of the form .
num use enough vibrators to properly compact the concrete .
have an additional standby vibrator in good operating condition for each concrete placing operation .
num get the engineers approval of the vibration procedure and of the number and types of vibrators before pouring .
num you may use external vibration in conjunction with internal vibration when the engineer so approves .
i. grout pump use grout pumps that can pump the fluid grout and maintain a uniform pressure of num lbsin² num kpa for at least num seconds .
j .
storage areas use plant storage areas that have surfaces capable of supporting the prestressed concrete bridge members without settlement .
ensure the storage area has blocks to support the units properly at the required points .
num .
substitution of reinforcement you may substitute welded wire fabric for the bar reinforcement shown on the plans .
the department will not pay extra for the substitution .
the substitution is subject to the following a .
design notes submit detailed shop drawings and design notes including any changes to the engineer for approval before using welded wire fabric .
b .
indicate on the design notes that the welded wire fabric will provide the same or greater strength as that provided by the bar reinforcing shown on the plans .
c. design fabric use according to the latest aashto specification for highway bridges .
prepare the drawings on num x numin num x num mm sheets .
d. have an engineer registered in the state of georgia stamp both drawings and notes .
e. design the yield strength for the wire fabric not to exceed num psi num mpa but not be less than num psi num mpa .
do not splice by welding or mechanical coupling .
f. if using welded wire fabric for stirrups of bar reinforcement embed the wires perpendicular to the axis of the beam at least num in num mm into the slab .
leave at most a clearance of num in num mm from the top of slab to the welded wire fabric .
g. embed at least two cross wires wires parallel to the longitudinal axis of the beam in the slab with the closer cross wire clearing the top of the beam by at least num in num mm .
h. you may use welded wire fabric in the anchorage zone at the ends of the beam to replace the stirrups that enclose the prestressing steel in the bottom flange and the vertical stirrups that do not protrude beyond the top of the beam .
i .
ensure that the wires perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the beam have the same steel area as that of the bar reinforcing .
j .
use either smooth or deformed wires for welded wire fabric .
use the aashto specification for highway bridges for the proper methods to embed and splice the fabric .
num .
substitution of strands you may use strands of different arrangement size or arrangement and size .
the department will not pay extra for the substitution .
the substitution is subject to the following structural and physical requirements a .
ensure that the net prestressed force of the strands after losses equals that shown on the plans .
b .
ensure that the ultimate strength of the member meets the applicable requirements of aashto specification for highway bridges .
c. ensure that the eccentricity pattern of the substituted strands is about the same as the pattern shown on the plans .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num d. before substituting strands submit to the engineer all changes and detailed shop drawings with design notes .
ensure that the design notes indicate compliance with the requirements .
prepare drawings on num x numin num x num mm sheets .
note if you propose to use strands that differ in size from those covered in astm a num submit complete data on the strands to the engineer for approval .
do not use individual strand couplings .
e. have an engineer registered in the state of georgia stamp both drawings and notes .
num .
concrete manufacture and mixing a .
manufacture and place concrete according to the requirements of section num. b .
mix the concrete according to subsection num.e and subsection num.d.num except when adding hrwr .
num when adding hrwr dose the hrwr at the casting yard under the direct supervision of the producers quality control .
do not exceed the hrwr manufacturers recommended dosage .
num after dosing mix the concrete at mixing speed for at least num revolutions .
note do not exceed num total revolutions at mixing and agitating speeds .
num after adding the plasticizer no additional mixing water will be permitted .
num .
concrete pouring fabricate the ends of all beams and girders to be vertical in the final erected position .
a. roughfloat the tops of beams at approximately the initial set .
b .
all nominal lengths shown on the plans are horizontal dimensions .
c. ensure that the fabricator adjusts the lengths as necessary to account for the final erected position of the member .
d. slope bearing assemblies to accommodate the erected position of the member .
num .
methods of prestressing you may either pretension posttension or combine these methods to prestress concrete bridge members .
a. pretensioning you may pretension with either the singlestrand or the multistrand jacking method .
note do not use strands from more than one source in any one tensioning operation .
ensure the method used meets these requirements num strand splices get approval from the engineer for splicing methods and devices .
jacking method action singlestrand use only one splice per strand .
multistrand splice all strands or no more than num of the strands .
ensure that the spliced strands have similar physical properties are from the same source and have the same twist or lay .
locate splices outside the prestressed units .
num wire failures the engineer may accept wire failures if the area of broken wires does not exceed num percent of the total area of the strands .
num stressing preparations prepare the members as follows a carefully place and thread all strands in the bed .
b avoid contaminating the strand with oil grease or other bond breaking material .
if any strand is contaminated clean the strand with a suitable solvent or replace the strand .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num c after final stressing position all strands within the location tolerances specified in subsection num.b.num .
d use strand vises designed for the size of pretensioning strand to anchor the strand .
e after anchoring ensure that the vises sustain the pretensioning force without slipping until the release of stress .
ensure that the vise grips seat no more than num in num mm each .
f to prevent strands from bonding together encase the strand in a conduit that can resist the pressure exerted by the concrete .
g use conduit with an id allowing free movement of the encased strand but no greater than the diameter of the strand plus num in num mm .
h secure the conduit to prevent both longitudinal movement along the strand and bonding at the location shown on the plans num in num mm .
i tape the conduit to keep concrete out .
use tape and conduit manufactured from a noncorrosive material compatible with both the concrete and steel .
do not debond the strand for the full length of members .
num pretensioning operation use elongation to control this operation .
ensure that the hydraulic pressure gauge readings at the time of the measured net elongation are within num percent of the calculated gauge reading for that particular elongation .
ensure that the net elongation and final gauge measurements agree within num percent of their computed theoretical values .
the measurements of force and elongation shall algebraically agree with each other within a num tolerance .
if any measurement varies by more than num percent the department will stop all work .
correct the defect before proceeding .
pretension the members as follows a initial tension after threading the strand in the bed apply an initial tensioning force to each strand .
do not use elongation to measure the amount of initial tension but use a dynamometer hydraulic jack gauge or dead weight .
b final tension calculate the final stress from the final elongation measured between established reference points .
use points that are independent of any movement in the bed or anchorages that might occur during the pretensioning operation .
calculate the design elongation as follows d pl ae where d design elongation in inches millimeters .
p tensioning force in pounds kilonewtons subtract the initial tensioning force from p. l distance from dead end anchorage to reference point measured in inches millimeters a crosssectional area of strand in square inches millimeters .
e modulus of elasticity of strand in pounds per square inch mpa .
c add correction factors to the design elongation for strand anchorage slip and temperature .
correct any movement in the anchorage abutments or in the overall anchorage system .
use the final elongation figure as the net elongation in jacking the strand .
d singlestrand jacking do not let the jack ram rotate more than one revolution while stressing any strand .
e draped strand jacking partially jack draped strands from the end of the bed to add tension .
raise or lower the strands to their final position to get the final tension .
ensure that the strands have no more than four points where the strand changes slope two of which shall be at each anchorage .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num use approved low friction devices at pickup and holddown points .
make the devices maintain the desired vertical and horizontal positioning of the strand .
after partial jacking deflect the strands to their final position in a sequence approved by the engineer .
f final readings after final stressing position all strands within the location tolerances specified in subsection num.b.num .
g calculate the final elongation according to subsection num.b.num.a.num.b .
uniformly distribute stress in the strands throughout the bed length .
num detensioning operation before detensioning submit the pattern and schedule for releasing the strands to the engineer for advance approval .
detension the members as follows a strip or loosen forms that tend to restrict the horizontal or vertical movement of the member prior to releasing the stress .
b if curing with steam carefully release the strand because of dimensional changes due to temperature and shrinkage changes .
where possible release the pretensioned strand while the units are moist and warm .
c in deflected strand construction immediately release the hold down devices within the member or members after curing with steam .
num stress release strength you may transfer stress to the concrete unless otherwise specified on the plans or in the special provisions based on the following requirements minimum strength determined by cylinders cast of the same concrete section minimum strength age concrete ibeams box beams flat slab deck sections or tee slab deck sections numpsi num mpa num hrs piling num psi num mpa other members as specified on the plans num strand release use the following table for each type of strand type of strand release single strand heat each strand and allow it to pull itself apart in the sequence of the approved pattern and schedule of release .
do not cut the strands .
multiple strand release either a symmetrical group of strands or all of the strands simultaneously .
remove the load on the strands from the anchorage and place it on the jacking system .
gradually release the jack or jacks until the strands are relaxed .
draped strand release according to a method where the weight of the beam is compared with twice the total amount of the vertical components of the holddown forces .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num use one of the following two methods method release as follows method i beam weight less than twice the total amount and vertical restraints can not counteract the vertical components of the hold down forces heat each draped strand at the end of each member to failure in the sequence of the approved pattern and schedule of release .
release holddowns and remove holddown bolts .
release straight strands as noted in subsection num.b.num.a.num method ii beam weight more than twice the total amount release holddown devices within the beam .
release the strands from the top to the bottom by either heating or jacking in the sequence of the approved pattern and schedule of release .
b. posttensioning use either the system required by the plans or an approved alternate system .
alternate systems may include the posttensioning of both straight and draped tendons .
ensure that the system meets the appropriate requirements that follow num tendons do not splice posttensioning tendons .
num ducts accurately position the ducts in which posttensioning tendons are placed and securely fasten them to prevent movement during concrete placement .
use flexible metal conduit metal tubing or other acceptable material for the ducts .
num stressing requirements prepare the members as follows a carefully thread tendons into the ducts .
b avoid contaminating the strand with oil grease or other bond breaking material .
if any strand is contaminated clean the strand with a suitable solvent or replace the strand .
c follow the stressing procedures and sequences approved by the engineer .
d after stressing anchor the tendons against the ends of the members and fill the ducts with grout .
num concrete strength stress the posttensioning tendons after the concrete in the member has reached the minimum strength and age requirements as follows minimum strength age num psi num mpa num days num psi num mpa num days c. posttensioning operation in general tension straight tendons from one end .
simultaneously tension draped tendons from each end .
pretension the members as follows num initial tension after threading the tendon in the duct apply an initial tensioning force of up to num percent of the final tensioning force with a jack .
determine the initial tension by reading the gauge .
do not use elongation to measure the amount of initial tension .
num final tension compute the final stress on tendons from the amount of the final elongation measurement checked by the jack pressure gauge reading .
num gauge reading ensure that the pressure gauge reading at the time of the measured elongation is within num percent of the calculated gauge reading for that particular elongation .
if the gauge pressure reading varies by more than num percent from the calculated reading stop the stressing operation and correct the defect before proceeding .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num num jacking while jacking draped tendons ensure that jack pressures and elongations are kept as near equal as is possible at each of the two jacks so the elongation measurements and jack pressures remain proportional .
num anchor devices design anchor devices that secure the tendon for the size of posttensioning tendon used .
after anchoring ensure that the devices can maintain a prestressed load of num percent of the maximum design load and do not slip more than num in num mm after anchoring .
place anchor devices exactly at right angles to the axes of the posttensioned tendons .
carefully note anchorage losses and take the proper corrective measures to ensure that the tendon has the final design stress .
num .
grouting a .
time limitations complete all grouting within num hours after posttensioning .
b. grout make grout to a consistency of thick paint .
num mix by volume num part portland cement num part max .
sand passing a no .
num num µm sieve and num part max .
water .
num within the limit specified vary the proportions of sand and water as required by the engineer .
num if you need to fill enclosures as hereinafter specified you may eliminate sand and use a neat cement grout in the mix .
num after adding all ingredients mix the batch for three minutes .
num make batches of grout small enough so that the batch may all be used up in less than num minutes .
num immediately before grouting blow out tendon ducts with compressed air .
ensure that the compressed air does not contain oil .
num vent each duct at each end .
ensure the vent has the means for positive closure when subjected to a minimum pressure of num psi num kpa .
num pump the grout into the duct towards an exit vent .
num after the grout has expelled all entrapped air and is flowing in a solid stream close the exit vent and build the pumping pressure to a minimum of num psi num kpa .
hold it at that level for a minimum of num seconds .
num close the grout entrance vent .
num do not move or disturb the member at all for at least num hours after grouting .
num .
concrete finish a. beams num finish the outside face of certain exterior beams specified in the table of bridge areas requiring a type iii finish in subsection num.ab with the type iii special surface coating finish .
num finish all other beams with a steel form finish .
num score the surfaces of the top flanges of all beams with a stiff wire brush or equivalent .
score the beams transverse to the longitudinal axis of the beams .
num transversely scrub the entire beam top with a coarse brush to remove all laitance and to produce a roughened surface for bonding to the slab .
remove all concrete fins or projections to produce a vertical face at the edge of the beam .
num if using prestressed concrete deck panels finish both sides of the beams top flange with a trowel for num in num mm from each panel edge to ensure a smooth and level bearing area .
b. superstructure deck units finish the riding surface of superstructure deck unitsflat slabs channels double tees etc.as specified in subsection num.t.num and the plans .
finish the traffic face and top face of curbs on exterior units and the outside face of certain exterior beams as specified in the table of bridge areas requiring a type iii finish in subsection num.ab .
c. substructure units finish the top surfaces of caps and piling with the type ivfloated surface finish specified in subsection num.ab.num .
d. patching the engineer will inspect all honeycombed areas .
the engineer may reject bridge members with extensive honeycombs within bearing areas .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num num patch as directed by the engineer as soon as possible after form stripping .
num the engineer may require that you use an epoxy bonding compound .
num remove holddown devices from the bottoms of the beams .
num coat the resulting holes with an epoxy bonding compound and plug them with grout .
num .
concrete curing cure concrete with one of the methods listed below .
provide means for keeping the temperature of bridge members above the freezing point for num days after concrete placement except for steam curing .
the department may reject bridge members based on improper curing .
a .
water curing cover all concrete surfaces that are not in contact with the forms with wet burlap or other suitable material .
keep the member wet for num days or until the concrete has reached the stress release strength specified in subsection num.b.num.a.num .
b .
steam curing do not begin steam curing for at least four hours after final placement of concrete .
num the engineer may delay the start longer if the concrete has not taken its initial set .
you may use sufficient heat during the delay to maintain the temperature of the concrete between num º and num ºf num º and num ºc .
num ensure the steam curing enclosures retain moisture and heat .
num after steaming begins you may raise the enclosure temperature at a maximum rate of num ºf num ºc per hour until the surface temperature of the concrete reaches an optimum temperature not to exceed num ºf num ºc .
num ensure that the differential surface temperature of the concrete within a member does not exceed num ºf num ºc during the curing period .
num continue steaming until reaching the stress release strength .
num lower the enclosure temperature at a maximum rate of num ºf num ºc per hour .
num maintain a film of water on all exposed surfaces of the concrete during the steam curing cycle .
num do not exceed the maximum temperatures .
num the department may reject bridge members based on excessive temperature .
c. heated forms when using approved heated forms keep the exposed surfaces of the concrete wet at all times .
num enclose the beds with a suitable weathertight covering supported to uniformly heat throughout the bed .
num apply the requirements stated in subsection num.b.num.b concerning the delay period temperature control curing duration and basis of rejection .
num .

manufacture prestressed concrete bridge members within the dimensional tolerances listed in sopnum standard operating procedures for precastprestressed concrete .
these tolerances generally will be the maximum deviation allowed although normal manufacturing tolerances will be well within those listed .
b .
the department may reject bridge members based on excessive deviations .

touch up all areas to be welded after the welded area has cooled and the weld is completed and cleaned .

marking note this requirement does not apply to single point pickup locations placed on piling .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num a .
with the exception of the departments inspection stamp the contractor is responsible for the placement and accuracy of all markings on bridge members according to these specifications .
b .
the inspector will not act for the manufacturer with respect to marking but will cooperate with the plant personnel to ensure that the work is properly done with respect to time of marking accuracy of description and accuracy of location of marks and lettering .
c. locate the markings so they are hidden after completing project construction .
d. do not ship any unit from the plant until it carries the official gdt stamp and number assigned by the department to the inspector at the plant nor until the inspector checks and approves the markings required by these specifications .
e. required markings clearly mark bridge members to indicate the project identification date of manufacture beam identification number properly located to coordinate with the erection drawing pile length and location of pile singlepoint pick up .
f. time of marking num before stress transfer immediately after forms are removed and before transferring stress individually identify and date members .
this helps keep accurate records on each members bed location and date of concrete placement .
num before shipping give the inspector advance notice of shipping .
after securing members for shipment apply marking consisting of the project identification to each member .
g. the inspector will place the gdt stamp and number on each member .
the inspector will not use the gdt stamp until after the members have been satisfactorily finished and stored .
num .
handling and storing a. prestressing steel protect all prestressing steel from contact with dissimilar metals to prevent galvanic action and excessive rusting .
num the department will not consider light rust that does not visibly etch the steel as detrimental .
num keep prestressing steel free of harmful materials such as grease oil wax clay dirt paint and loose rust .
num use special care to keep prestressing steel free of form oil and other bondreducing material that may be used on the forms .
num handle prestressing steel at all times in such manner as to prevent kinks and nicks .
the department will not allow prestressing tendons that have kinks nicks bends or other defects .
num do not use torches or welding equipment adjacent to tensioned strand unless the strand is insulated against heating or burning .
b. reinforcement steel handle place and support all reinforcement steel according to the requirements of section num. c. prestressed concrete bridge members handle store and ship prestressed concrete bridge members in a way to eliminate the danger of cracks fractures and excessive bending stresses .
handle members by the two embedded pickup points unless the engineer approves other methods .
num except for piling handle members so their vertical axes remain plumb at all times .
num support members in storage on firm blocking located immediately below the two embedded pick up points .
in multiple layer storage support members in the stack with blocks of uniform thicknesses and in a vertical line .
num set all blocking at right angles to the longitudinal axis of the member and the longitudinal axis of the blocking shall be horizontal .
do not ship members until the concrete reaches its ultimate design strength .
note replace members that were damaged in handling or storage at no additional expense to the department .
however the engineer may determine that the damage is minor and may approve use of the member .
d. piling handle store and ship piling after stress release .
num the department may reject any piling cracked in handling storing or loading if the crack warrants .
section nummanufacture of prestressed concrete bridge members num num the department will reject any cracked piling destined for locations involving sea water or alkali soils .
num mark rejected pile as rejected .
num store piling in groups with the same length .
num transport piling in a manner approved by the engineer .
upon request the engineer will furnish drawings giving the limits of truck bolster spacing for various sizes and lengths of piling .
e. beams handle or store fully pretensioned beams after stress release .
num use pickup and support points within num ft num mm of the beam ends .
num support beams on firm blocking located within num ft num mm of the permanent bearing area of the beam .
num you may handle or store fully posttensioned beams num hours after the grout has been placed in the tendon ducts .
num for beams manufactured by the combined method of pretensioning and posttensioning you may handle and store them after the pretensioning phase is completed .
do not handle again until num hours after grout placement .
num do not ship beams and other superstructure units until after their strength reaches the required minimum num day design strength .
num store beams in single layers not in stacks .
support beams so they meet the following requirements concerning warp and sweep twist of vertical axes of the ends of beams due to misalignment of blocking the maximum deviation between the vertical axes of the ends of beams shall be num inft num mmm of beam height .
tilt of vertical axis of an end of beam from the vertical due to deviation of blocking from the horizontal the maximum deviation of the vertical axis of an end of a beam shall be num inft num mmm of beam height .
lateral sweep due to manner of storage there shall be no discernible sweep induced by the manner in which a beam is stored .
c. acceptance num .
plant inspection a .
give notice to the engineer give the engineer ample notice before starting work so that the engineer can inspect all plant facilities involved in the production .
do not manufacture anything until the engineer approves all facilities .
b .
facilities for inspection allow free access to the inspector to all parts of the plant involved in the production process .
c. inspector authority the inspector has the authority to reject materials or quality of work that do not meet the specifications .
in cases of dispute the contractor may appeal to the engineer whose decision will be final .
num .
rejections if any material or finished members are defective they will be rejected even though the inspector may have accepted them .
a .
promptly replace rejected material or quality of work or make it good at your own expense .

curing cure the units with one of the following methods until the minimum compressive strength has been achieved or for num hours whichever comes first .
a .
method num num place the units in a curing chamber free from outside drafts and cure them in a moist atmosphere not exceeding num f num c. num use steam injection for the time and temperature needed to obtain proper curing .
num construct the curing chamber and place the units so that steam may fully circulate around the entire unit .
b .
method num num keep the units wet by covering the concrete not in contact with the forms with wet burlap or other suitable material .
num protect the units from freezing between when you place the concrete until curing is complete .

accepted units or finished units will be rejected at any time if found to be defective .

asphalt properties section numbituminous adhesive for raised pavement markers num determine the base asphalt properties based on the material obtained from the following extraction and abson recovery methods a .
extract the asphalt by heating the adhesive to the point where it will easily flow .
b .
add num to num g of adhesive to num ml of trichloroethylene that has a temperature of num to num f num to num c. c. stir the mixture to dissolve the asphalt .
d. decant the trichloroethyleneasphalt mixture .
e. recover the asphalt using the abson recovery method described in astm d num except do not use the extraction methods of astm d num and do not filter the solventasphalt mixture .
f. centrifuge the extraction solution of trichloroethylene and asphalt for at least num minutes at num times gravity in a batch centrifuge .
g. decant the solution into a distillation flask .
do not include any filler sediment .
h. apply heat and bubble carbon dioxide slowly until the solution reaches a temperature of num f num c. i .
increase the carbon dioxide flow to between num to num ml per minute .
j .
maintain the decanted solution temperature between num and num f num and num c with this carbon dioxide flow for at least num minutes and until the trichloroethylene vapors are completely removed from the distillation flask .
k. repeat the extractionrecovery method as necessary to obtain the desired quantity of asphalt .
l. determine penetration num f num c viscosity and viscosity ratio with the recovered asphalt .
num .
viscosity ratio determine the num f num c viscosity ratio by comparing the num f num c viscosity on the base asphalt before and after the thinfilm oven test .
a .
perform the thinfilm oven test as described in astm d num. b .
determine the specific gravity with a pycnometer as described in astm d num for use in the thinfilm oven test .
c. calculate the num f num c viscosity ratio by dividing the viscosity after the thinfilm oven test by the original num f num c viscosity .
num .
filler material separate the filler material from the asphalt to determine filler content and filler fineness .
a. filler content num determine the portion by weight of the adhesive that is insoluble in num num numtrichloroethane by weighing num num g of solid adhesive into a centrifuge flask with a volume of approximately num ml as specified in astm d num .
num add num ml of num num numtrichloroethane to the adhesive .
num break the adhesive into small pieces to dissolve the solids .
num place the sample flask in a balanced centrifuge and spin with a minimum relative centrifugal force of num as determined in section num of astm d num for num minutes .
num remove the sample flask and decant the solvent without losing any solids .
num repeat the application of solvent and centrifuging until the solvent is clear and the filler is visually free of asphalt .
num dry the filler at num num f num num c to remove solvent and weigh the resulting filler .
section numbituminous adhesive for raised pavement markers num num filter the decanted solvent to verify that no filler was lost .
num calculate the percent filler content as follows filler content by weight g filler wt .
g x num original adhesive wt .
g b. filler fineness num determine filler fineness according to astm c num using no .
num num µm no .
num num µm and no .
num num µm sieves .
num modify this method by using a watersoluble nonionic wetting agent such as triton xnum to aid the wetting action .
use a surfactant solution that is approximately num percent by weight .
num thoroughly wet the numgram dry sample in the surfactant solution .
num soak the sample for num minutes .
num transfer the filler to the sieve cup .
num spray water on the filler for two minutes .
num add surfactant solution as needed and physically disperse clumped particles .
num dry the sample and handle as directed in astm c num .
the department will reject any bituminous adhesive if it meets all requirements of this specification but fails in actual use .

section numpaint num general description this section includes the requirements for all paints including pigments vehicles and the compositions of prepared paints for all purposes specified .
num related references a .
standard specifications general provisions num through num b. referenced documents qpl num qpl num sop num aashto m num military specifications milenum b milpnum or us corps of engineers specification cnum federal test methods standard no .
num section numpaint num federal specifications astm ttenum ttpnumb ttpnumb ttpnumc ttpnum ttpnuma ttpnume ttrnum tttnum ttvnum d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num d num e num g num num materials a .
requirements num .
ingredients the engineer shall approve all paint ingredients .
mix the paints in the proportions specified in this section for each kind of paint .
the formulas given represent the proportions by weight of the materials to be used .
num .
condition of mixed paints ensure that mixed paints do not liver or curdle and that the pigments remain in suspension to a reasonable degree satisfactory to the engineer .
num .
filling and packaging the manufacturer shall strain paints before filling the containers .
the manufacturer also shall ship paints in strong substantial containers according to qpl numand qpl num plainly marked with the paint name and number color volume manufacturer name and address date of manufacture and the manufacturers lot number on every package .
the inspection stamp on the paint container will be evidence of approval .
traffic line paint manufactured for the department shall be delivered in num gallon num l drums or num gallon num l totes .
the manufacturer shall stencil on the head of each drum the kind of paint requisition number purchase order number and gross and net weights .
ensure that the drums are the removable head types .
ensure the totes are labeled appropriately .
num .
finished paints unless otherwise specified deliver paints to the project or the department completely mixed and ready for use without adding oils or thinner .
use well ground paints that do not settle or badly cake in the container and can readily be broken up to a smooth uniform paint with good brushing consistency .
when brushed or rolled on a smooth vertical surface the paint shall dry hard and elastic without running streaking sagging or spotting .
use paint for spray application that sprays satisfactorily and does not run sag or streak .
the first coat of paint applied in the shop or in the field to uncoated structural steel or wood is called the primer coat .
the paint covering the primer coat is called the second coat and the paint covering the second coat is called the third coat .
b .
fabrication the formulas given in this specification represent proportions by weight .
c. acceptance num .
testing test methods for paint analyses shall be according to the federal test methods standard no .
num or the astm standard methods of tests for paint .
num .
color match color visually by comparing with standard color chips obtained from the office of materials and research .
num .
inspection section numpaint num inspection and analysis will be made at the point of manufacture according to sop num .
the manufacturer shall assist as necessary permit the inspector to test the ingredients before the paint is made and witness the paint grinding .
the department reserves the right to sample and test all paint at any time before it is used .
num .
tolerances the department will accept a tolerance of num percent of the required value for the paint formulation and property requirements .
exception this tolerance does not apply where maximum and minimum values are noted .
d. materials warranty the following people shall furnish the department a certificate of analysis and manufacturers guarantee the manufacturer of each brand of paint submitted for acceptance under these specifications all contractors proposing to use any paint specified in this section ensure that the certificate of analysis shows the paint trade name to be furnished including a facsimile of the label if the paint is readymixed and an analysis showing the percentage of each of the chemical elements and compounds in the pigment and vehicle .
the guarantee shall assert that all paint furnished conforms to the analysis shown on the certificate filed and to the statement of percentages of ingredients shown on the labels which are required to be on each container .
the guarantee shall be sworn to by a person having authority to bind the manufacturer into an agreement num paints for structural steel a .
requirements num .
use structural steel paint that meets the applicable requirements of subsection num and the following no .
numa red primer see table num .
apply this paint with brush roller or airless spray .

apply this paint with brush roller or airless spray .
no .

fabrication num .
no .
numb aluminum prepare the aluminum paint by thoroughly mixing aluminum paste with mixing vehicle .
a .
ensure the paints are well ground do not settle or cake badly in the container and are readily broken up to a smooth uniform paint of good brushing consistency .
b .
use num lbs num kg of paste to num gal num l of vehicle .
mix this at the factory .
section numpaint num c. ensure a thorough mix with a minimum of stirring .
ensure that the paint shows satisfactory leafing qualities and solidly covers in one coat without running streaking or sagging .
d. if applying two coats of aluminum paint tint the first coat with iron blue paste to help distinguish the two coats .
c. acceptance see subsection num.c .
d. materials warranty see subsection num.d .
num traffic line paints a .
requirements use traffic line paints that meet the applicable requirements of subsection num and the following num .
no .
numc black traffic line paint a .
paint composition see table num. b .
finished paint num flexibility ensure paint flexibility by following this procedure a use a doctor blade or other suitable means to apply the paint to a numguage num mm clean tin plate panel .
apply to a wet film thickness of approximately num mils num mm .
b dry the panel in a horizontal position for num hours and then bake it for num hours at num f to num f num c to num c. c cool the panel to approximately num f num c and bend double over a ½ inch rod num mm rod .
ensure that the film does not show cracking or flaking upon bending or straightening .
num color ensure that the paint dries to a pure flat black and furnishes the maximum amount of opacity and visibility under both daylight and artificial light .
ensure that the paint does not discolor when exposed to weather or traffic and does not appreciably discolor with stains during service life on either concrete or bituminous surfaces .
num weight per gallon liter use paint weighing at least num lbgal num kgl at num f num c. num consistency the paint viscosity when measured at num ºf shall be num to num krebs units .
num moisture content the paint shall contain no more than num water .
num drying the paint shall dry to no pickup within num minutes when tested according to astm d num .
num spraying the paint shall be factorymixed ready for application through spray machines without using thinners .
num storage the paint shall not cake liver thicken curdle gel or show other objectionable properties after storage for num months .
num coarse particles and skins the paint shall not contain more than num percent of coarse particles and skins .
num fineness of grind the paint shall have a grind of num to num hegman scale .
num packaging the finished paint shall be passed through a no .
num mesh screen while filling the containers .

num miscellaneous paints a .
requirements num .
paint for steel piling and sway bracing use paint for steel piling and sway bracing that meets the requirements of subsection num and the following a .
no .
nump general ensure that materials used as a primer andor finish coat are formulated from either a coal tar pitch or a native pyrobitumen resin .
you may use other types of material if they meet the requirements in table num below .
table numprimerfinish coat requirements properties requirements color black odor ensure coal tar materials have no pyridine pyridine base or tar acid odor .
consistency easily applied by brush or spray to a coverage of num ft²gal num m²l without sagging yielding film thicknesses of about num mils num mm wet and num mils num mm dry .
drying time apply at a rate of num ft²gal num m²l .
ensure that the material dries to a firm film within num hours at num num f num num c and can receive a second coat .
section numpaint num properties requirements chemical resistance ensure that the material remains intact and in good condition when immersed for num days in each of the following inorganic acids alkalies and salts num sulfuric acid num hydrochloric acid num phosphoric acid num sodium hydroxide num sodium chloride num calcium chloride num durability before initially accepting a product to be supplied under this specification the complete systemfrom primer when required to finish coatsshall be subjected to accelerated weathering and atmospheric exposure tests according to astm d num and astm g num type d. num ensure that the system remains intact without cracking and prevents significant steel corrosion for at least num hours exposure in the accelerated weathering test and num years atmospheric exposure in a coastal environment .
num the state materials engineer may approve systems that perform satisfactorily for up to num hours of accelerated weathering pending completion of the numyear atmospheric exposure tests .
num after the department initially accepts the material you do not need to test each lot of material .
however the department will conduct other durability tests at its discretion .
b .
no .
nump special provisions coating use special protective coatings instead of any other coating required by the specifications for steelh piling steel sway bracing metal shells for castinplace concrete piling or prestressed concrete piling in all intermediate bents of the cap and pile trestletype .
num get approval from the laboratory for the protective coating material .
num use a twocomponent chemically cured coaltar epoxy that meets the requirements of either type i class num military specification milpnum ships or u.s .
corps of engineers specification cnum .
num ensure that the coating exhibits optimum chemical and physical resistance to alkalies and mineral acids under continuous immersion service .
num ensure that the cured coating withstands considerable physical abuse such as direct impact abrasion and flexing .
num furnish a written certification to the engineer that the material meets the requirements of these specifications .
num .
galvanizing repair compound use a compound that meets the general requirements of subsection num and table num .
table numgalvanizing repair compound requirements maximum minimum paint composition percent by weight pigment num num vehicle num num pigment composition percent by weight zinc dust federal specification ttpnum num num section numpaint num maximum minimum dust metallic zinc powder type num lead suboxide stabilizer num suspending agent num vehicle composition percent by weight nonvolatile vehicle num volatile vehicle num a. nonvolatile vehicle use chlorinated rubber and a suitable plasticizer for the nonvolatile portion of the vehicle .
ensure that the chlorine content based on the nonvolatile vehicle is at least num percent by weight .
b .
volatile vehicle use a volatile vehicle that is completely compatible with the other ingredients of the finished product .
ensure that the vehicle meets all the physical and chemical requirements of the end product .
c. finished compound ensure that the finished compound meets the requirements of table num .
table numfinished compound requirements characteristic requirement condition in the container no pigment component of the readymixed compound settles .
when the package remains unopened for one year you can readily disperse the pigment by hand mixing .
the vehicle does not liver curdle or show excessive bodying .
application the material to repair galvanizing and to galvanize welds in the field shall be such that when applied there is no unusual difficulty in horizontal vertical or overhead positions .
adhesion expose test panels coated according to field application specifications to weather for at least num months in a position num degrees vertical facing south .
after this time ensure that the test panels show no visible signs of peeling or flaking .
gassing no build up of gas or excessive pressure in the container when stored at room temperature for num months .
dry film thickness the compound leaves a dry film between num num mils num num mm thick when applied according to field application specifications .
drying time the compound is set to touch in num minutes and is dry to recoat in num hours .
the material is thoroughly hard within num hours after application .
hardness dry and cure the test panels coated under these specifications for at least num hours .
brush a section by hand with a wire brush .
continue brushing until you see bright metal .
measure the dry film thickness .
accept the material if the brushing does not reduce the film below the specified thickness .
characteristic requirement consistency viscosity at num f num c is num num krebs units as measured by the stormer viscometer .
weight per lb liter num num lbs num num kg at num f num c. packaging commercial paint packaging is acceptable for containers smaller than num gal num l. for num gal num l packages use no .
num gauge steel pails .
do not pack more than num gal num l of compound in a single container .
storage store the compound where the temperature stays above num f num c. section numpaint num num .
aluminum caulking compound use a compound that meets the requirements of subsection num third bullet and table num .
table numaluminum caulking compound requirements properties max .
min .
compound composition percent by weight pigment num vehicle num pigment composition percent by weight calcium carbonate astm d num type gc num mineral filler num aluminum paste federal specification ttpnumc type ii class iii num titanium dioxide astm d num type ii class ii num vehicle composition percent by weight nonvolatile num refined vegetable oil num polybutene oil num fatty acid num thinner and drier num color aluminum a .
other properties properties requirement consistency can be applied by hand caulking gun knife or trowel .
adhesion good adhesion to any dry dustfree or oilfree surface .
curing a light film forms in num to num hours .
a tough metallic film develops in num to num weeks .
exposure good resistance to water and weather .

section numwater num general description this section includes the requirements for water used in portland cement mixtures .
num related references a .
standard specifications general provisions num through num .
b. referenced documents aashto t num aashto t num astm c num gdt num num materials num water for portland cement mixtures a .
requirements num .
use water that is reasonably clear without oil salt acid alkali organic and other injurious substances .
num .
the department may allow drinking water that is used for ordinary household use without testing it .
num .
do not use water from shallow muddy or marshy surfaces .
test and approve all other sources before using them .
section numwater num num .
when the source of water is relatively shallow ensure that the source depth and intake exclude silt mud grass and all other foreign material .
num .
do not use water with detergents that will entrain air in portland cement concrete .
num .
do not use water with impurities above the following limits impurity concentration acidity or alkalinity calculated in terms of calcium carbonate num total organic solids num total inorganic solids num sulfate sonum num chloride num b .
fabrication general provisions num through num .
c. acceptance the department will reject any water that when compared with accepted water shows any indication of unsoundness marked change in time of set or reduction of more than num percent in mortar strength .

can withstand normal field handling and construction operations without damage .

num section numepoxy resin adhesives num general description this section includes the requirements for the most common epoxy adhesives used in highway construction or maintenance .
num related references a .
standard specifications general provisions num through num .
b. referenced documents aashto t num astm num federal hazardous products labeling act gdt num qpl num num materials num epoxy resin adhesives a .
requirements num .
use the types of epoxy adhesives below a .
type ir rapidsetting marker adhesive for bonding raised pavement markers to pavement .
b .
type is standard setting marker adhesive for bonding raised pavement markers to pavement .
c. type ii epoxy adhesive for bonding plastic concrete to hardened concrete .
d. type iii epoxy adhesive for bonding hardened concrete to hardened concrete or for bonding miscellaneous materials such as metals .
e. type iv epoxy adhesive for creating an epoxy mortar for use with clean concrete or mortar sand .
f. type v epoxy adhesive for repairing cracks in concrete by intrusion grouting .
g. type vi epoxy adhesive for a complete application or as a component in the application of a skid resistant or protective coating on hardened portland cement concrete or asphaltic concrete .
h. type vii discontinued .
i .
type viii epoxy adhesive used for anchors and dowel bar implants .
do not use in sustained tension load applications .
either mix this epoxy by machine to the proper ratio or package it in a twocomponent cartridge with a mixing nozzle that thoroughly mixes the two components as they are dispensed .
use a nozzle at least num in num mm long .
num .
furnish the epoxy adhesive as two separate components .
num .
viscosity ensure that the viscosities of the separate components are similar and conducive to easy blending of the epoxy adhesive system .
a .
submit the viscosity for the epoxy adhesive system to the engineer .
b .
ensure that the viscosity of the mixed system is compatible with the intended use of the system .
section numexpoxy resin adhesives num num .
labeling clearly label each container of the separate components of an epoxy adhesive system with the following information specification number and type component designation a or b manufacturers batch numbera batch is a single charge of all components in a mixing chamber expiration date shelf life for separate components in original containers mixing ratio and directions by volume or weight as designated by the manufacturer potential hazards and precautions according to the federal hazardous products labeling act num .
stencil the component designation on the top of each container .
num .
physical requirements ensure that the mixed epoxy adhesive system meets the applicable requirements of table num .
b .
fabrication general provisions num through num .
c. acceptance each epoxy adhesive system shall meet the requirements of this section .
if the department qualifies or disqualifies a system for one of the types specified it will not affect the qualification or disqualification of any other type .
the department will reject any epoxy adhesive system that meets all the requirements of this section but fails in actual use .
for a list of sources see qpl num .
